Number: 1
一 one line radical
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
1 stroke
PK, DUH, PN

ONYOMI: ICHI, ITSU

"Eazy-es debut album "EAZY duz it" was so good, ITS going to go to number one on the charts."

DESCRIPTION:

KUNYOMI:

ひと*つ
    one thing
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

もう一度 ( もういちど )
    one more time!
    一 (one) + 度 (times) = もう一度 (one more time!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
一緒 に ( いっしょ に)
    together
    一 (one) + 緒 (together) = 一緒 (together)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
一人 で ( ひとり で)
    one person, alone (FP)
    一 (one) + 人 (person) = 一人 (one person, alone)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
一般的 な ( いっぱんてき な)
    One of many many Japanese words for normal. The nuance of いっぱんてき　is ordinary, non-special - as opposed to a member of a special group of people of things. 一般的な人 means, an average person. As in, an average person is not allowed in this Yakuza bar.
    一­般 (generally, commonly) + 的 (motivation or -al) = 一般的 (ordinary)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
一日 ( ついたち )
    first day of the month (FP)
    一 (one) + 日 (sun, day) = 一日 (first day of the month)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
一番 ( いちばん )
    the best! Number one! (NEO)
    一 (one) + 番 (number) = 一番 (number one!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 2
二 two
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
2 strokes
DUH

ONYOMI: NI

as in, "Vince NEIL has two chins."

KUNYOMI:

ふた*つ
    two things
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

二人 で ( ふたり で)
    two people (FP)
    二 (two) + 人 (person) = 二人 (two people)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
二月 ( にがつ )
    February (KANA)
    二 (two) + 月 (moon) = 二月 (February)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
二日酔い ( ふつかよい )
    hangover (literally: paying for your drink） (SARC)
    二 (two) + 日 (sun, day) + 酔 (drunk) = 二日酔い (hangover)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
二日 ( ふつか )
    second day of the month
    二 (two) + 日 (sun, day) = 二日 (second day of the month)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
二重 XXX (にじゅう XXX)
    PREFIX meaning double, as in "double-chin" or "twin-engine plane." (PRE)
    二 (two) + 重 (heavy or overlap) = 二重 (double-xxx)
    Star-16

    三 (three) + 月 (moon) = 三月 (March)

Number: 4
了 total
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
2 strokes
BETA, PK

ONYOMI: RYOU

as in, "We dont have the total number of parts, so we need to REORDER more."

To me it just looks like a broken coat hanger, which is totally useless.
JUKUGO:

完了 する ( かんりょう する)
    to finish work on a project - an annual report, a re-formatting of the database, etc. (NP)
    完 (complete) + 了 (total) = 完了 (finish)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
了解 ( りょうかい )
    roger that! (I got it!) (originally used by military, but now often used when you text, because of its brevity)!
    了 (total) + 解 (solve or untie) = 了解 (OK, got it.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
終了 ( しゅうりょう )
    to expire, to come to an end (used about contracts or subscriptions expiring) (NP)
    終 (end) + 了 (total) = 終了 (expire)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
子 	child 	the one radical 	一
了 	total 	NO one radical 	
予 	beforehand 	katakana MA 	マ

A child is ONE year old.

The complete kanji is complete even WITHOUT the one radical.

MAMA was around before baby.

USED IN:

    子



Number: 5
子 child
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
3 strokes
PN
一 (one or line radical) + 了 (total)

ONYOMI: SHI

That poor child ーSHE has lived a total of one year!

DESCRIPTION: From now on, when you see a kanji with the onyomi of "KO", please use 子供 (KOdomo) for the English keyword.

KUNYOMI:

こ
    child
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

子供 ( こども )
    child (KUNKUN)
    子 (child) + 供 (accompany) = 子供 (child)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
親子 ( おやこ )
    parents and child together - also the rather cruel name for a traditional dish: boiled chicken served with scrambled eggs. (KUNKUN, SARC)
    親 (parents or kindness) + 子 (child) = 親子 (meat and eggs)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
調子 ( ちょうし )
    the condition somethings in. Can be used with a living thing or object. Always used only with いい or 悪い. Usually emphaizes the LONG TERM condition. Although hungover people have been heard to remark, 調子が悪い！
    調 (check out) + 子 (child) = 調子 (condition)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
椅子 ( いす )
    chair (FP, 1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
車椅子 ( くるまいす )
    wheelchair (NEO, KUNKUN)
    車 (car) + 子 (chair) = 車椅子 (wheelchair)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
子 	child 	the one radical 	一
了 	total 	NO one radical 	
予 	beforehand 	katakana MA 	マ

A child is ONE year old.

The complete kanji is complete even WITHOUT the one radical.

MAMA was around before baby.

Number: 6
女 woman
Star-16
3 strokes
PK, SYMBOLIC

ONYOMI: JO

as in, "Jack Off."

It looks like a lady, tilting her head to one side and crossing her arms as she watches you JACK OFF. She really disapproves of it!!!

KUNYOMI:

おんな
    woman - but dont say it by itself, its like saying That broad.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

女の子 ( おんなのこ )
    girl . Newspapers use it for a female up through junior high, but guys talking about chicks,dude might use it to refer to a 20 year old.
    女 (woman) + 子 (child) = 女の子 (girl)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
彼女 ( かのじょ )
    her. Might also mean girlfriend depending on context.
    彼 (him) + 女 (woman) = 彼女 (her or girlfriend)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
女の人 ( おんなのひと )
    the polite- but not formal - way to say woman
    女 (woman) + 人 (person) = 女の人 (woman)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
少女 ( しょうじょ )
    young girl - usually 5- 15 years old.
    少 (a little (amount)) + 女 (woman) = 少女 (young girl)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
女子 ( じょし )
    PREFIX used about women from first grade through college. Used to refer to female students as a group: "女子 line up on the left side of the class, 男子 (danshi) line up on the right side." BOOBOO: You wouldnt say "Shes a joshi." (PRE)
    女 (woman) + 子 (child) = 女子 (female xxx or xxx for girls)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
女性 ( じょせい )
    female - emphasizes biology, (sex, rather than gender).
    女 (woman) + 性 (sex or essential nature) = 女性 (female)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
女子高生 ( じょしこうせい )
    high school girl.
    女­子 (PREFIX used about women from first grade through college. Used to refer to female students as a group: "女子 line up on the left side of the class, 男子 (danshi) line up on the right side." BOOBOO: You wouldnt say "Shes a joshi." ) + 高 (tall) + 生 (life or birth) = 女子高生 (high school girl.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 7
好 like
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
6 strokes
子 (child) + 女 (woman)

ONYOMI: KOU

Your Moms likes exercising her COLON on Youtube.

A woman and her child means like, huh? Think you can handle the linguistics by yourself, Noam Chomsky??

KUNYOMI:

( が ) す*き
    to like
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
この＊む
    To have a preference for.
    Star-16Star-16
この＊み
    The noun form of 好む. You often say, Thats my konomi, meaning Thats my favorite kind . . . but it also implies that you know a lot about that thing.(***)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

大好き ( だいすき )
    really like
    大 (big) + 好 (like) = 大好き (really like)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
格好 ( かっこう )
    literally, look or shape, as in Hes dressed as a woman : おんなの格好してる。

    But　usually it means coolness: かっこいい (cool) or かっこうわるい (not).(when used in the figurative, cool sense, it is usually KANA) (1 or 2 KANA)
    格 (character, aspect) + 好 (like) = 格好 (looks)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
格好つける ( かっこうつける )
    this is a rad one. it means "try too hard to be cool". (Literally "manufacturing coolness") (KANA)
    格 (character, aspect) + 好 (like) = 格好つける (try too hard to be cool)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
好奇心 ( こうきしん )
    curiosity

    BOOBOO: if you want to say youre curious about a specific thing, youd use 興味　（きょうみ） instead.

    好奇心 usually means "curiosity-in-general": 　you have an inquiring personality, or a gaze of curiosity on your face. Youd never say, "Oh, you play in a band? 好奇心ある！”
    好 (like) + 奇 (strange) + 心 (heart) = 好奇心 (curiosity)
    Star-16



Number: 8
姦 rape
Star-16
9 strokes
FR, ABU, BETA
女 (woman)

ONYOMI: KAN

Genghis KHAN raped three women.

DESCRIPTION:By looking at the radicals you can see how Politically Incorrect Ancient China was when they were inventing kanji. You see three women and youd assume the kanji would mean something positive, like sisterhood or a cheerleader human pyramid. Buuuuuut no.
JUKUGO:

強姦 する ( ごうかん する)
    rape (FP)
    強 (burly) + 姦 (rape) = 強姦 (rape)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
法定強姦 ( ほうていごうかん )
    statuatory rape (NP)
    法 (law) + 定 (plan) + 強­姦 (rape) = 法定強姦 (statuatory rape)
    - zero stars! -
近親相姦 ( きんしんそうかん )
    incest (ABU)
    近 (near) + 親 (parents or kindness) + 相 (partner) + 姦 (rape) = 近親相姦 (incest)
    - zero stars! -
獣姦 ( じゅうかん )
    bestiality (ABU)
    獣 (beast) + 姦 (rape) = 獣姦 (bestiality)
    - zero stars! -
死姦 ( しかん )
    necrophilia (ABU)
    死 (death) + 姦 (rape) = 死姦 (necrophilia)
    - zero stars! -



Number: 9
口 mouth or small box radical
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
3 strokes
PK, DUH, SYMBOLIC, PN, JERK RADICAL

ONYOMI: KOU, KU

- as in, "My KUchi on your COLON . " Disgusting? Yes!. . . but try forgetting this ON-yomi now.

You can think of this as an open mouth, just yelling at you . Always yelling! Again with the yelling JESUS WOULD YOU SHUT UP ALREADY JUST SHUT UP. YEAH THATS RIGHT. JUST CALL THE COPS. GREAT!

DESCRIPTION: JERK RADICAL ALERT- although the kanji means mouth the radical sometimes means "box". Irritating but not totally a hassle when you consider that it looks more like a box than a mouth, anyway.

Also, jukugo with 口 tend to be KUNKUN for some reason.

KUNYOMI:

くち
    mouth
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

出口 ( でぐち )
    exit. (KUNKUN)
    出 (pull out or hand over) + 口 (mouth) = 出口 (exit.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
入り口 ( いりぐち )
    entrance (often shortened to 入口） (NOKURI)
    入 (put or go in) + 口 (mouth) = 入り口 (entrance)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
悪口 ( わるぐち )
    talking shit about someone. (KUNKUN)
    悪 (bad) + 口 (mouth) = 悪口 (talking shit about someone.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
銀行口座 ( ぎんこうこうざ )
    bank account
    銀­行 (bank) + 口 (mouth) + 座 (sit) = 銀行口座 (bank account)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
人口 ( じんこう )
    population
    人 (person) + 口 (mouth) = 人口 (population)
    Star-16Star-16
窓口 ( まどぐち )
    the kind of depressing place where you get a ticket or food from a person in a box with usually a bulletproof plexiglas window between you and them. (KUNKUN)
    窓 (window) + 口 (mouth) = 窓口 (service window)
    Star-16Star-16
口説く ( くどく )
    pester someone, usually for sex
    口 (mouth) + 説 (explain) = 口説く (pester)
    Star-16Star-16
口実 ( こうじつ )
    a pretext. Like, "Im studying to be a preacher, but thats just a pretext for me to meet virgin dudes."
    口 (mouth) + 実 (truth) = 口実 (pretext)
    Star-16

Number: 10
品 products
Star-16Star-16Star-16
9 strokes
BETA, PN, DUH
口 (mouth or small box radical)

ONYOMI: HIN

Please show HIM the boxes of products. (hes the customer)
JUKUGO:

商品 ( しょうひん )
    items for sale, merchandise
    商 (merchandise) + 品 (products) = 商品 (items for sale, merchandise)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
作品 ( さくひん )
    artworks.
    作 (make) + 品 (products) = 作品 (artworks.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
下品 な ( げひん な)
    crude. Like chicks sitting with their legs open or guys picking their nose.
    下 (below) + 品 (products) = 下品 (crude)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
新品 ( しんぴん )
    brand new shit - just on the market
    新 (new) + 品 (products) = 新品 (new items)
    Star-16Star-16
上品 な ( じょうひん な)
    can be used of people or things. It means graceful or sophisticated in a quiet or understated way. When it comes to people, 上品 is usually used about women, I mean ladies.
    上 (above) + 品 (products) = 上品 (sophisticated)
    Star-16

Number: 11
言 say
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
7 strokes
SYMBOLIC half the time
一 (one or line radical) + 三 (three) + 口 (mouth or small box radical)

ONYOMI: GEN

He used his mouth to say it 4 times already! If he says it AGAIN, I swear Ill stomp that ass.

KUNYOMI:

( と ) い＊う
    to say
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

言葉 ( ことば )
    ANY word - unlike the related term 単語（たんご）、　言葉 can refer to compound words, or onomonopoeia. Also 言葉 can mean "way of speaking." There are expressions like "watch what you say!" that use 言葉 this way: 言葉使い が丁寧 (her way of speaking is very polite!) or 言葉大切につかいましょう （lets be careful how we speak!) (FP)
    言 (say) + 葉 (leaf) = 言葉 (any word)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
助言 ( じょげん )
    advice
    助 (save) + 言 (say) = 助言 (advice)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
言語の壁 ( げんごのかべ )
    the language barrier (NEO)
    言 (say) + 語 (language) + 壁 (wall) = 言語の壁 (the language barrier )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
片言 ( かたこと )
    we say "He speaks broken English".Japanese say, "He speaks katakoto nihongo." (KUNKUN, FP)
    片 (fragment) + 言 (say) = 片言 (broken english or Japanese)
    Star-16Star-16
言葉遣い ( ことばづかい )
    ones choice of words (KANA)
    言 (say) + 葉 (leaf) + 遣 (apply) = 言葉遣い (ones choice of words)
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 13
不 un
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
4 strokes
BETA, PRE
下 (below) + 一 (one or line radical)

ONYOMI: FU

as in, "Doing meth is FUcking unlucky, and really FUcking unwise. "

below (下) + one stroke. You can think of 不運 (unlucky) or 不平等 (unfair) as being below or less than lucky or fair.
JUKUGO:

不思議 ( ふしぎ )
    a mystery or unexplainable thing. BOOBOO:NOT a mystery like Sherlock Holmes or "Colonel Mustard, in the drawing room, with the double-headed dildo." A mystery like how fat Americans are, or why Sting is famous. Thats a fushigi.
    不 (un) + 思 (think) + 議 (discussion) = 不思議 (mystery)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
不安 な ( ふあん な)
    unease
    不 (un) + 安 (cheap or safe) = 不安 (unease)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
不便 な ( ふべん な)
    inconvenient
    不 (un) + 便 (convenient　 or  poop) = 不便 (inconvenient)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
不足 ( ふそく )
    To not have enough of a physical thing (money, time, nurses, teachers.) Also implies that there is a specific amount that is required, For example -犬不足 (a dog shortage). Theres no particle or verb needed. (NP)
    不 (un) + 足 (foot or  be enough) = 不足 (shortage of)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
不倫 ( ふりん )
    an affair - cheating
    不 (un) + 倫 (principles) = 不倫 (affair)
    Star-16Star-16

USED IN:

    歪
    杯
    衆
    否



Number: 14
否 no
Star-16Star-16
7 strokes
不 (un) (Same-ON) + 口 (mouth or small box radical)

ONYOMI: HI

HE said no, when I asked if hed get a tattoo of me and him holding hands naked.

The mouth is un-happy so it says no.

KUNYOMI:

いな
    No. Usually used by older people. Or pretentious authors, who contradict themselves for rhetorical effect: She was a proper woman, No, wait, perhaps I should rather say she was the kind of woman who wanted to be seen as proper, A-ha-ha, I am so clever.
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

否定形 ( ひていけい )
    a negative sentence. He doesnt , we dont, I can not, are examples of English negatives. ひていけい is a good word to know if you want to ask your friends, How do you use this word in the negative?
    否­定 (a formal word for to deny (the politician denied the allegations)) + 形 (form) = 否定形 (a negative sentence)
    Star-16Star-16
否定 する ( ひてい する)
    a formal word for to deny (the politician denied the allegations) (NP)
    否 (no) + 定 (plan) = 否定 (a formal word for to deny (the politician denied the allegations))
    Star-16Star-16
拒否 する ( きょひ する)
    absolute refusal- unlike 拒む (こばむ）,　拒否 is always verbal - an exit line. Like if you tell a guy no thanks 10 times and he wont go away, you use 拒否. As in, 私がきょひした。’

    Oh no you diint! (ABU)
    拒 (repel) + 否 (no) = 拒否 (refuse!!!!)
    Star-16Star-16



Number: 15
十 ten
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
2 strokes
PK, COUNTER

ONYOMI: JUU

JEWS gave us the ten commandments, the foundation of Western morality.

KUNYOMI:

とお
    (also　pronounced just と）ｔｅｎ　ｔｈｉｎｇｓ　（ｙｅｓ,　ｉｔ　ｈａｓ　ｔｗｏ　ｐｒｏｎｕｎｃｉａｔｉｏｎｓ）
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

十円 ( じゅうえん )
    ten yen.
    十 (ten) + 円 (yen or circle) = 十円 (ten yen.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
十月 ( じゅうがつ )
    October (FP, KANA)
    十 (ten) + 月 (moon) = 十月 (October)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
十日 ( とおか )
    the tenth day of the month
    十 (ten) + 日 (sun, day) = 十日 (the tenth day of the month )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
十ヶ月間 ( じゅっかげつかん )
    ten months time
    十 (ten) + 月 (moon) + 間 (a period of time) = 十ヶ月間 (ten months time)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
二十歳 ( はたち )
    twenty years old - traditionally the age at which Japanese turn into adults and get presents, kimono, etc. So, naturally it has its own special pronunciation that doesnt make any sense, since it SHOULD be called にじゅうさい。 Whatever. Tradition. (FP, CCW)
    二 (two) + 十 (ten) + 歳 (years old) = 二十歳 (twenty years old)
    Star-16
十戒 ( じっかい )
    the ten commandments. (FP)
    十 (ten) + 戒 (admonish or commandment) = 十戒 (the ten commandments.)
    - zero stars! -

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    used XXX (books, cars, your dads condoms)

    Star-16Star-16Star-16
古着 ( ふるぎ )
    used clothes - a used clothes store is a 古着屋（ふるぎや） (KUNKUN)
    古 (old) + 着 (wear or arrive) = 古着 (used clothes)
    Star-16Star-16
古典的 な ( こてんてき な)
    classical, like Shakespeare or Bach or Shunga something.

Number: 18
計 measure
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
9 strokes
DUPE
言 (say) + 十 (ten)

ONYOMI: KEI

its OKAYYY to measure your pubic hair.

Measure SATAN!!!!! (say + ten) Hes just huge, dude!!

KUNYOMI:

は*かる
    measure temprature, height, depth. If youre measuring a chair or your moms stretch marks, use this one.
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

時計 ( とけい )
    watch or clock (FP)
    時 (time) + 計 (measure) = 時計 (watch or clock )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
合計 ( ごうけい )
    total
    合 (to suit) + 計 (measure) = 合計 (total)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
計画 ( けいかく )
    Pretty close to 予定　（よてい） in meaning, but perhaps more elaborate - youd use 計画 to say "I have a plan to get rich!" or to say "I planned out our whole vacation to 3 countries." . . but you wouldnt use 予定。 (FP)
    計 (measure) + 画 (a drawing) = 計画 (plan)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
余計 な ( よけい な)
    excessive, uncalled-for, and unnecessary (usually used in the context of 余計なお世話だよ！　（よけいなおせわだよ！）: Mind your own business!)
    余 (excess) + 計 (measure) = 余計 (uncalled-for)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
計算 する ( けいさん する)
    to calculate
    計 (measure) + 算 (calculate) = 計算 (to calculate)
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 20
七 seven
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
2 strokes
PK
Heel (heel) + 一 (one or line radical)

ONYOMI: SHICHI

SHE CHEATS seven times.

Lets call the one radical a dirty needle, for reasons which shall become clear.

You can tell the difference between heel and seven with the following mnemonic:

Seven heels get pierced with ONE dirty needle.

DESCRIPTION: 4 and 7 are numbers that dont follow the usual pronunciation rules. When counting time or months, usually one uses the KUNs, but with 4 and 7 you use the ONs.

KUNYOMI:

なな
    seven
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
なな＊つ
    seven things
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

七月 ( しちがつ )
    July (FP, KANA)
    七 (seven) + 月 (moon) = 七月 (July )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
七時 ( しちじ )
    7 oclock (FP)
    七 (seven) + 時 (time) = 七時 (7 oclock)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
七千円 ( ななせんえん )
    ７，０００ yen.
    七 (seven) + 千 (thousand) + 円 (yen or circle) = 七千円 (７，０００ yen.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
七日 ( なのか )
    the seventh day of the month (FP)
    七 (seven) + 日 (sun, day) = 七日 (the seventh day of the month)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
七面鳥 ( しちめんちょう )
    turkey
    七 (seven) + 面 (front surface or face) + 鳥 (bird) = 七面鳥 (turkey )
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

比較的 ( ひかくてき )
    comparatively (BOOBOO: you DONT use a na at the end, for some reason) (NP)
    比­較 (a more formal word for compare: Youd 比べる AC or DC albums to see which one rocked the most, but youd 比較 the GDP of developing nations.) + 的 (motivation or -al) = 比較的 (comparatively)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
比較 する ( ひかく する)
    a more formal word for compare: Youd 比べる AC or DC albums to see which one rocked the most, but youd 比較 the GDP of developing nations. (NP)
    比 (compare) + 較 (evaluate) = 比較 (compare)
    Star-16Star-16

    ratio

Number: 23
日 sun, day
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
4 strokes
SYMBOLIC, COCK, PK, COUNTER
口 (mouth or small box radical)

ONYOMI: NICHI, JITSU

Frederich NIETSZHIE spends every day doing ju JITSU.

(all "Hiyahh!!!! Ubermench takedown!!" Philosophy was just a side-job; something he did to finance his bid for Ultimate Fightin Champion.)

You shouldnt need a damn story for this, but I am drunk so here goes: Two mouths. One yelling, "Dont look at the sun you idiot." and the other yelling, "Dood it will be awesome, You can see sun men all hanging out in there smoking sun -reefer, I swear to god, man, this dude told me it, go ahead."

DESCRIPTION: As a radical, it usually means "bright".

COCK: This kanji has not one but two ON-yomis, and as if that wasnt enough, most of the jukugo dont use either of them! This is by far the worst kanji when it comes to not following the rules of pronunciation. Luckily, most of the FP words youll use every day, right from your first day in Noob Nihongo, so youll learn em without even trying.

Also, it means "Japan" - a sort of contraction of 日本.

KUNYOMI:

ひ
    a day
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

昨日 ( きのう )
    yesterday (FP)
    昨 (yesterday) + 日 (sun, day) = 昨日 (yesterday)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
今日 ( きょう )
    today (FP)
    今 (now) + 日 (sun, day) = 今日 (today)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
明日 ( あした )
    tomorrow (FP)
    明 (bright) + 日 (sun, day) = 明日 (tomorrow)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
ｘｘｘ 曜日 (ｘｘｘ ようび )
    Day of the week (BOOBOO； in practice, most Japanese omit the final 日.So, 木曜日(もくようび） becomes simply 木曜 (もくよう）) (COUNTER, SUF)
    曜 (day of the week) + 日 (sun, day) = 曜日 (day of week)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
日米 ( にちべい )
    add 日, (which is short for 日), to 米, (which somehow means "America"), and you have a word which means "East-and-West" or "East meets West." Usually seen on cultural exchange-related things.
    日 (sun, day) + 米 (rice or America) = 日米 (east-and-west)
    Star-16

Number: 24
旨 the gist
Star-16
6 strokes
COCK, SOLO
Heel (heel) + 日 (sun, day)

ONYOMI: SHI

SHE cant really put her heels over the sun, but the gist is shes tall!

DESCRIPTION:This is a COCK because the overwhelming majority of words which use 旨 mean "the gist of," but youll never use those words! The only time youll see it is in the context of 旨い（うまい）、which has nothing to do with gists!

KUNYOMI:

うま＊い
    this is a really good word, meaning delicious! or well done! (1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
( XXXの ) むね
    ２ meanings： 1 -write to someone to the effect that xxx. 　

    ２： the main purpose or goal. Not so useful, but gives you a good idea of why this is called the gist.
    - zero stars! -

USED IN:

    脂
    指



Number: 25
昆 insect
Star-16
8 strokes
BETA
日 (sun, day) + 比 (compare)

ONYOMI: KON

as in, The insects are eating a pine CONE

Although the bottom radical is "compare," it might be easier to think of it as two heels. Thus,
The sun shines down on the many heels of multi-legged insects scurrying around

DESCRIPTION: The normal word for insect is 虫　（むし）. 昆 is a more formal, scientific term and is not used very much.
JUKUGO:

昆虫 ( こんちゅう )
    insect, (a more scientific term than むし) (NP)
    昆 (insect) + 虫 (insizzect) = 昆虫 (insect)
    Star-16

昆 	insect 	SUN 	陽

Everyones heels trample on WHITE people,

but the SUN shines on insects that crawl on the high QUALITY bamboo.

    Star-16

    to be moved or rescheduled earlier in time　－to be done in a hasty or premature way.
    Star-16

素早い ( すばやい )
    physical speed or agility, but without any advanced kung-fu techniques. A fast bird or lizard. Doing a simple task at the office, but very speedily.

	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical

巣 	habitat 	TREE 	木
単 	merely 	BABY BIRDS 	Hay

The SUN rises early.

The habitat is in a TREE.

Merely has NO TREE because it is MERELY some baby birds.

    面 (front surface or face) + 白 (white) = 面白*い (interesting)

but the SUN shines on insects that crawl on the high QUALITY bamboo.
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
賛 	agree 	MONEY 	貝
替 	substitute 	DAY 	日
皆 	everyone 	HEEL 	Heel

Two husbands agree about MONEY (i.e. it is awesome)

but every DAY they substitute one for the other in a game of wife-swapping.

Everyone has a HEEL fetish.
USED IN:

    階

    Wednesday
    水 (water) + 曜­日 (Day of the week (BOOBOO； in practice, most Japanese omit the final 日.So, 水曜日(すいようび) becomes simply 水曜 (すいよう)) = 水曜日 (Wednesday)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

Ice has the SNOWFLAKE on top, water doesnt. So you can say, "Water doesnt have a SNOWFLAKE because water is warm."
If it has been icy for ever, there are TWO SNOWFLAKES piled up on top of each other!

ONYOMI: EI

"Fonzie" is the keyword for the EI onyomi, because that was his catchphrase on the show. "EYYYY!" Back in 78, that was the most coveted t-shirt: a half-sleeve jersey with The Fonz giving a thumbs-up and reciting EYYYY!! Thats right, Im old. Didnt ever get that shirt, neither!

Anyway, mnemonic-wise, we can now say that. . .. Fonzie has been icy cool since forever.

永 consists of ice (氷） plus a dot, which we will, in a blaze of inspiration, call a second snowflake. So now we can say, "Its been icy forever, so we have more than one snowflake. Theyre piled on top of each other! Its been snowing forever!"

    forever - the science word. (BOOBOO : the poetic word is eien.(永遠))
    永 (forever) + 久 (been a long time) = 永久 (forever )

Ice has the SNOWFLAKE on top, water doesnt. So you can say, "Water doesnt have a SNOWFLAKE because water is warm."
If it has been icy for ever, there are TWO SNOWFLAKES piled up on top of each other!

Number: 41
月 moon or organ
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
4 strokes
SYMBOLIC, PK, PN, JERK RADICAL, COUNTER
(left radical)

ONYOMI: GETSU

The United States had to GET TO the moon before the Russians, because whoever got freaky with Moon Bitches first would get so much rep, the other countrys game would never recover.

DESCRIPTION: JERK RADICAL ALERT: by itself, it means month or moon, but usually as a radical it has an entirely different meaning :"organ of the body." Some dudes will point out that the 月 Radical is actually a MUTANT RADICAL for 肉、but who cares? Stop being so pedantic with your pale ass.

BOOBOO: when you say the actual proper names of months, you pronounce it GATsu!!!That really is hard to remember.

In fact, I still mix the two up ９0％ of the time.

So, for my own benefit as much as your own, heres a mnemonic： You GOT TO leave in January, if you want your rocket to GET TO the moon.

    the moon

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    last month

    this month

三ヶ月間 ( さんかげつかん )
    three months time, three months duration
    三 (three) + 月 (moon) + 間 (a period of time) = 三ヶ月間 (three months time)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
正月 ( しょうがつ )
    the New Year - (BOOBOO: in Japan, that means not just January first but the whole first week)
    正 (correct) + 月 (moon) = 正月 (the New Year)

炊 	cook rice 	LACK 	欠

A streetlight is on top of a pole or a NAIL,

but you LACK water to boil some delicious kale.

Number: 64
化 transform
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
4 strokes
SUF
Man (personleft) + Heel (heel)

ONYOMI: KA

The CAR transforms into Optimus Prime.

OK, I know hes supposed to be a truck or whatever, but I never liked that show anyway. I was fucking with Papa Smurf and Raydeen and shit.

The witch transformed that person into a giant heel.

DESCRIPTION: Youll often see 化 as a suffix, meaning "xxx - ization." For instance, 機械化(きかいか）means "the mechanization of society. The industrial revolution." Most of these words are not worth learning, but theres a LOT of them, so at least learn the suffix meaning.

KUNYOMI:

( が or に ) ば＊ける
    transform - this is ONLY used in the context of a person changing to a ghost, or a curse transforming a person into a werewolf. In other words, it is not used that often.
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

変化 する ( へんか する)
    transformation, change
    変 (change) + 化 (transform) = 変化 (transformation, change)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
文化 ( ぶんか )
    culture
    文 (culture or  sentence) + 化 (transform) = 文化 (culture)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
進化 ( しんか )
    evolution
    進 (progress) + 化 (transform) = 進化 (evolution)
    Star-16Star-16
機械化 ( きかいか )
    the mechanization of a society or of an industry.
    機­械 (A machine, particularly something with a motor in it which moves when activated. A computer is not a 機械, but a robot arm is. ) + 化 (transform) = 機械化 (mechanization )
    Star-16

    花
    靴
    傾

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    within xxx (as in, "Ill be there within 10 minutes!")

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
内緒 ( ないしょ )
    usually defined as confidential, but that makes it sound more serious than it is - like a spy document or something. Actually, 内緒 is kind of a kids word. "Keep this information between us two." (KIDS)
    内 (the inside) + 緒 (together) = 内緒 (confidential)

Inside (George Michaels Moustache) + 人 (person)

    muscle
    筋 (muscle) + 肉 (meat) = 筋肉 (muscle)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
皮肉 ( ひにく )
    sarcasm OR irony. Japanese DO have a sense of sarcasm,(for example, calling the traditional chicken-and-scrambled-eggs dish "parents and child") but it is so different than the Western say-the-opposite-of-what-you-mean style that Japanese dont have a word for western sarc. So they seem to have taken their word for Irony and pressed it into service for sarcasm as well. (SARC)
    皮 (skin) + 肉 (meat) = 皮肉 (sarcasm or irony)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
豚肉 ( ぶたにく )
    pork (KUNKUN)
    豚 (pig) + 肉 (meat) = 豚肉 (pork )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
焼肉 ( やきにく )
    roast meat, usually beef. (NOKURI)
    焼 (roast or grill) + 肉 (meat) = 焼肉 (roast meat, usually beef.)
    Star-16Star-16
牛肉 ( ぎゅうにく )
    beef
    牛 (cow) + 肉 (meat) = 牛肉 (beef)
    Star-16Star-16

    ７，０００ yen.
    七 (seven) + 千 (thousand) + 円 (yen or circle) = 七千円 (７，０００ yen.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    １００ yen
    百 (hundred) + 円 (yen or circle) = 百円 (１００ yen)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    100,000,000 YEN,　 AKA what Maneki-neko wants!
    一 (one) + 億 (a hundred million) + 円 (yen or circle) = 一億円 (100,000,000 YEN)

Number: 82
停 bring to a halt
Star-16Star-16
11 strokes
BETA
Man (personleft) + 亭 (restaurant) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: TEI

The police person brings a halt to the restaurant because too many people got a damn nail in their sandwitch and what the hell kind of deal is that, anyway? Imagine the pain!!
JUKUGO:

バス停 ( ばすてい )
    bus stop
    Star-16Star-16
停止 する ( ていし する)
    suspension or stoppage (i.e. they cut my electricity because I didnt pay the bill). This is usually used in official announcements or bills. You wouldnt say to your friend, "I 停止-ed watching TV." (NP)
    停 (bring to a halt) + 止 (stop) = 停止 (suspension or stoppage)
    Star-16Star-16
各駅停車 ( かくえきていしゃ )
    sure this is a scary and long word, but if you live here, youll use it everyday： It means "local train" (literally, "stopping at each station train")
    各 (each) + 駅 (train station) + 停 (bring to a halt) + 車 (car) = 各駅停車 (local train)
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 84
方 direction or method or person
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
4 strokes
JERK, STRONG
Lid (beret) + ク (katakana ku)

ONYOMI: HOU

You go in that direction of a a fine-looking HOE who is wearin a beret!

DESCRIPTION: a big JERK - it also means METHOD and PERSON.
Although, not so bad if you look at the equivalent English: When you want to learn how to use your new toy, you do what? Read the DIRECTIONS.

KUNYOMI:

かた
    two meanings:

    1) method.

    2) a somewhat formal, polite term for　ｐｅｒｓｏｎ (i.e. 日本の方 means a person from Japan) (F)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

xxx 方 (xxx かた )
    SUFFIX meaning, way to do. for instance, ギターを弾く； means to play the guitar. so,ギターの弾き方； means the way to play the guitar. (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
方法 ( ほうほう )
    method
    方 (direction or method or person) + 法 (law) = 方法 (method )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
仕方 ( しかた )
    way to do something. (Most often used in the negative: Shikata ga nai. as in, fuck it. )
    仕 (work) + 方 (direction or method or person) = 仕方 (way to do something. (Most often used in the negative: Shikata ga nai. as in, fuck it. ))
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
方向 ( ほうこう )
    direction
    方 (direction or method or person) + 向 (turn to face) = 方向 (direction)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
一方 に ( いっぽう に)
    one-sided, one-way. Often used in the phrase : xxx 一方だ！ (meaning, more and more xxx - i.e. "more and more hot", "more and more popular," etc.)
    一 (one) + 方 (direction or method or person) = 一方 (one-sided)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
方 	direction or method or person 	HEAD 	
万 	10000 	EVEN ON TOP 	

方 means person, so naturally it has a little head stiking up on top - you can think of that as the persons beret!
万 is a number, so naturally it has NO HEAD. Its EVEN on top - which makes sense because 10,000 is an even number.

Number: 85
万 10000
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
3 strokes
COUNTER
一 (one or line radical) + ク (katakana ku)

ONYOMI: MAN

You can think of this as the katakana KU (ク) plus the number one over it.
A MAN touches your KUchie with ONE finger. ten thousand times!!

DESCRIPTION:Japanese count big money in units of 10,000. They dont for instance, have a word for million. -- a million is actually called 100万. Which would be logical if it were written with 万-sized commas： 100,0000 . . . but its written with rest-of-the-planet commas, like this: 1,000,000. Im sure some asshole thought he was doing the rest of the world a favor with this compromise, but actually that just makes it more confusing for everyone. Probably it was the same motherless douche who decided to import all the on-yomi from China and get them all wrong.
Anyway.

KUNYOMI:

( 一 ) まん
    10,000 (LAZY)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

方 means person, so naturally it has a little head stiking up on top - you can think of that as the persons beret!

Number: 94
済 economy or to be over
Star-16Star-16Star-16
11 strokes
JERK
水 (waterleft) + 斉 (unison)

ONYOMI: SAI

Alan Greenspan played the economy like a XYLOPHONE.

Water moving in unison can be harnessed by electric dams to power the economy. Boring!

DESCRIPTION: JERK - the SOLO meaning is to be over, but the jukugo usually have to do with the economy.

KUNYOMI:

( を ) す＊ます
    to get through doing something (usually a chore or homework); to finally pay off debts. Sometimes used like this: ｘｘｘをすませる。(Finish your xxx!)
    Star-16Star-16
( が ) す＊む
    something is finally over, something is finally finished (1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

経済 ( けいざい )
    the economy (経済学（けいざいがく）= economics)
    経 (experience) + 済 (economy or to be over) = 経済 (the economy (経済学（けいざいがく）= economics))
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
済 	economy or to be over 	WET 	水
斉 	unison 	CULTURE 	文
剤 	type of medicine 	SWORD 	刀

The economy is all WET. Our CULTURE cries out in unison for some medicine in the form of a SWORD to cut deficits.

Number: 102
思 think
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
9 strokes

ONYOMI: SHI

KUNYOMI:

( と ) おも＊う
    To think (BOOBOO: 思う　should not be confused with the other think (考える　（かんがえる））. 思う is like, "I think your Moms is the source of the fungus." "I think the theater is over there." 考える is more like thinking to solve a problem: thinking about physics or math.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

思い出す ( おもいだす )
    to remember something

    This word uses the particle を　（even though plain ole 思う uses と !!)

    （BOOBOO: dont do like me and spend 3 years confusing 思い出す with 覚える、 which means to memorize.)
    思 (think) + 出 (pull out or hand over) = 思い出す (remember)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
思い出 ( おもいで )
    a specific memory (BOOBOO : GENERAL memory - as in, "Im losing my memory!" - is a different word : 記憶 (きおく))
    思 (think) + 出 (pull out or hand over) = 思い出 (a memory)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
思い出せない ( おもいだせない )
    I dont remember
    思 (think) + 出 (pull out or hand over) = 思い出せない (I dont remember)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 105
忙 busy
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
6 strokes
SOLO
心 (leftheart) + 亡 (dying) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: BOU

Im too busy to go BOWLing with my compadres, so my heart is dying inside.

KUNYOMI:

いそが*しい
    busy (1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
忙 	busy 	NO TIME LEFT 	
忘 	forget 	BOTTOM OF YOUR HEART 	

Both kanji are"heart + dying," but, in busy (忙). . .the heart is on the LEFT, because youre so busy you have no time LEFT.

With forget(忘), the heart is on the bottom, because you are apologizing to your boss FROM THE BOTTOM OF YOUR heart for forgetting to bring the report to the big meeting.

Number: 110
慢 neglect or  egotistic
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
14 strokes
BETA, COCK, JERK
心 (leftheart) + 日 (sun, day) + Net (net) + 又 (again or crotch radical)

ONYOMI: MAN

The egotistical MAN neglected his heart and let the sun shine on his crotch instead.

DESCRIPTION:COCK: 90% of the words using this kanji mean egotistical, neglectful OR even chronic (for example, 怠慢,meaning negligence, dereliction )

But of course since this is Japanese, the one exception - 我慢 (meaning patience) is used 90% of the time!!
JUKUGO:

我慢 する ( がまん する)
    to endure, to bear something. Often translated as patience, but that is not quite right. You have patience if you can do data entry on a fucking kanji dictionary for 5 hours straight, but you gaman with your overtime or while taking final exams with a burst appendix.

    Masochists tend to gaman when theyre fed worms while tied up.

    Sometimes the concept of gaman DOES overlap with the English idea of patience, though: Little kids have to gaman if they find out that Disneyland is still 4 hours away.

    One possible way to make GAMAN fit with the theme of neglect is to remember that the ga part means self. So GAMAN means neglect yourself, or, more poetically, Stop feeling the pain of your body and mind, and concentrate on the task at hand. (CCW, 1 or 2 KANA)
    我 (we) + 慢 (neglect or  egotistic) = 我慢 (persevere)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
自慢 する ( じまん する)
    to brag
    自 (my own) + 慢 (neglect or  egotistic) = 自慢 (to brag)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
慢 	neglect or  egotistic 	HEART 	心
漫 	manga 	WET 	水

You neglect your lover with your cheating HEART, but it takes WET ink to make manga art.


Number: 111
漫 manga
Star-16Star-16
14 strokes
BETA
水 (waterleft) + 日 (sun, day) + Net (net) + 又 (again or crotch radical)

ONYOMI: MAN

The main difference between this and the other "まん” kanji (慢) is that the left-hand radical of 漫 is WATER.

So picture a MAN using a net to haul old manga out of the water and dry them in the sun so he can read them.

    whats that??? (1 or 2 KANA)

    漫­画 (whats that??? ) + 家 (home) = 漫画家 (manga artist)

You neglect your lover with your cheating HEART, but it takes WET ink to make manga art.


Number: 112
亜 sub-
Star-16
7 strokes
PRE, PK
Net (net) + ??? (???)

ONYOMI: A

As for the shape, I got nothing!

Well. . . theres a net and what looks like a roman numeral II. So if youre an ancient Roman, you have your regular net which you use to catch your prey, and if that breaks, then you have your #II net, a sub-net, which you keep in reserve.

DESCRIPTION: BOOBOO: people think this means "ASIA," but it doesnt. A while ago, just as a pun, some Japanese decided to spell the word "ASIA" phonetically, using kanji, like so: 亜細亜：あじあ: but this custom never caught on. And besides, the 亜 kanji was only chosen for its sound, not for its meaning.

亜 is used in a lot of names of elements, like chalk or zinc, but unless youre a research chemist or terrorist, this doesnt concern you.
亜種：あしゅ： subspecies
亜熱帯：あねったい： subtropical region
See what I mean?
USED IN:

    悪

    outside
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    Star-16Star-16Star-16
( が or に ) はず＊れる

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    above

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
( を ) あ＊げる
    to literally raise (your hands, and wave them from side to side; the roof)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
( に ) のぼ＊る
    rise up : Sometimes literal (climb a ladder, go up hill) , but usually figuragive ( To rise to stardom, a cost that runs as high as a billion annually).
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
( xxx ) じょう
    SUFFIX meaning, in terms of. For example, ネット上 (hes big on the internet, but not really anywhere else) or 歴史上 (historically) (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16

以上 ( いじょう )
    ２ meanings. usually said when you finish ordering something (food, copies, condoms) ； Thatll be all. It also means, "on top of all that" or "more than" (used like xxx以上、or sometimes also 以上　のｘｘｘ） (JERK)
    以 (compared to) + 上 (above) = 以上 (more than or thats all)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
上手 な ( じう な)
    skillfully done! Usually used to praise ones friends efforts (at art, music, cooking, etc.) (FP)
    上 (above) + 手 (hand) = 上手 (skilllfully done!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
上級 の ( じょうきゅう の)
    advanced level. When you finish this book, youll still be a beginner of kanji but youll have advanced level skills at making people aware of problems in life that their Moms might face.
    上 (above) + 級 (level) = 上級 (advanced-level)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
目上の人 のひと ( めうえ のひと)
    someone who out-ranks you - at work, school, or in society. (KUNKUN)
    目 (eye) + 上 (above) + 人 (person) = 目上の人 (higher person)
    Star-16

Number: 132
喧 fight or quarrel
Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
SIDEKICK
口 (mouth or small box radical) + 宣 (announce)

ONYOMI: KEN

DESCRIPTION: Heres the time youll mostly see this: 喧嘩(kenka), meaning "a fight".
喧嘩 is an interesting jukugo, because BOTH kanji are SIDEKICKS; they are normally only encountered with each other.
It makes sense to study this as one big kanji.
Sure, it’s a a complicated mess of lines, but check it out: both kanji have the ‘mouth’ radical on the left side.
‘S far as I know ,there ARE NO OTHER jukugo where that is true. So don’t even learn the rest of the ‘kenka’ radicals! Concentrate on the mouths: think of two people fighting, both with their mouths open and yelling like some Springer shit. You’ll be ok.

KUNYOMI:

やかま＊しい
    annoying because noisy or loud - can be used of a person OR place.
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

喧嘩 する ( けんか する)
    to fight or argue (KANA)
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 136

Star-16Star-16

KUNYOMI:

    Star-16Star-16

    (a more figurative idiom): in accordance with XXX, we will do YYY. (NP)
    Star-16

浴 	bathe 	PEAKED ROOF 	Peaked roof
沿 	run parallel to 	NO ROOF 	

So you bathe under a PEAKED ROOF for privacy.

Outdoors (i.e. where there is NO ROOF), you run parallel to the river.

    台 (big thing counter) + 湾 (bay) = 台湾 (Taiwan )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    one big thing, well, bigger than 一個(いっこ) anyway... 一個 is used for apples, marbles, maybe a melon. 一台 is used for anything from a TV set on up to a car! (COUNTER)
    一 (one) + 台 (big thing counter) = 一台 (one big thing)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

態度 ( たいど )
    an attitude or manner (defiant, peaceful, etc.) or stance (anti-trade, pro-shinto, anti-corporate). When it comes to the first meaning, 態度 is something you can tell just by looking at the person - they might not be doing it intentionally.
    態 (looks like) + 度 (times) = 態度 (attitude or  stance)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
状態 ( じょうたい )
    the state or status of something: water is the liquid state of h20, but ice is the solid state. State of shock. Pristine state. Also can mean the state of affairs : good, bad, deadlocked, deteroriorating, improving.
    状 (circumstance) + 態 (looks like) = 状態 (state)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
擬態語 ( ぎたいご )
    擬態語 is a　very Japanese concept - a sound effect for something that doesnt make noise - usually emotional states. The only English example of 擬態語 I can think of is  bling. (1 or 2 KANA)
    擬 (sham) + 態 (looks like) + 語 (language) = 擬態語 (emotional sound-effect)

The bear is ON FIRE,

but you look like my HEARTs desire.

    spicy hot, not fresh-from-the-oven hot (BOOBOO)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
つら＊い
    something is tremendously difficult or painful to do - (the life of a coal miner is hard!).

    Not only does つらい have nothing to do with からい, but they both LOOK the same: 辛い、辛い. - so theres no way to tell which is which! (although usually つらい is written in hiragana, and からい is written with kanji ) (1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Luck has a TEN on top, spicy does NOT. So you can say,

Good luck will bring you TEN TIMES AS MUCH happiness as good spices .

The man with the CROWN manages the country.

Its pitch black so youll have to use your bat-like echolocation and find the gate using sound.

KUNYOMI:

やみ
    absolute darkness
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
闘 	struggle 	BEANS 	豆
闇 	pitch-black darkness 	SOUND 	音
閥 	clique 	PERSON 	人

BEANS make you struggle with farts, and you hear the SOUND even in a pitch-black room.

Cliques are made of a PERSON or people!


Number: 163
間 a period of time
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
SUF
門 (gate) + 日 (sun, day)

ONYOMI: KAN

It CAN take a period of time of up to a day to go from one gate (門) to the other.

KUNYOMI:

あいだ
    an interval of time - the time between event A and event B.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
ま
    space - never used by itself, though. Only in jukugo - sort of like a second ONyomi. (see below!) (NUBI)
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

時間 ( じかん )
    time
    時 (time) + 間 (a period of time) = 時間 (time)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
間違い ( まちがい )
    a mistake (1 or 2 KANA)
    間 (a period of time) + 違 (different and therefore wrong) = 間違い (a mistake)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
ｘｘｘ 間 (ｘｘｘ かん )
    xxx amount of time.

    You cant just say "one year" like in English. You have to add kan, the equivalent of saying, in English, one years time.

    for instance:

    一年間 (いちねんかん）:one years time

    三週間 (さんしゅうかん）: three weeks time

    With months, it gets even more complex: you have to add 間 at the end AND ヶ (pronounced ka) in the middle, like this:

    三ヶ月間 (さんかげつかん）: three months time (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
人間 ( にんげん )
    human (FP)
    人 (person) + 間 (a period of time) = 人間 (human)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
に 間に合う (に まにあう )
    to make it in time - catching your train or not being late for class (this is the main time you use the "MA" pronunciation)
    間 (a period of time) + 合 (to suit) = 間に合う (make it in time)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
門 	gate 	OPEN 	Open
間 	a period of time 	DAY 	日
問 	question, problem 	MOUTH 	口

Gate has NOTHING IN THE CENTER, ITS OPEN - so you can walk through it.

There is an interval of one DAY between things, and you ask a question with your MOUTH.

USED IN:

    簡



Number: 164

    to ask (BOOBOO: only used in a formal situation, where the wrong answer spells trouble: - the police questioned the suspect, the situation calls his authority into question) (F)

JUKUGO:

質問 する ( しつもん する)
    a question - usually used in a structured setting: interview, trial, test.　

    BOOBOO: in casual conversation, people will say 尋ねる　or 聞く instead of 質問.
    質 (quality) + 問 (question, problem) = 質問 (question)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
問題 ( もんだい )
    problem - as in "environmental pollution", also as in "homework problem"
    問 (question, problem) + 題 (topic) = 問題 (problem)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
疑問 ( ぎもん )
    a doubt　（疑問がある＝ I have doubts about it.)
    疑 (doubt) + 問 (question, problem) = 疑問 (a doubt　)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:

問 	question, problem 	MOUTH 	口

Gate has NOTHING IN THE CENTER, ITS OPEN - so you can walk through it.

There is an interval of one DAY between things, and you ask a question with your MOUTH.

Number: 168

ONYOMI: SHOU

JUKUGO:

昭和 ( しょうわ )
    Showa Era： (In Japan, a new　時代 (era) begins every time a new Emperor is crowned, and lasts until the next one is crowned. The Japanese - like Pol Pot - start counting from Year One every time they enter a new era.

    The era doesnt use the Emperors real name, but his official nickname, which seems a bit informal, but try being logical with an emperor-lover and see where it gets you.

    Anyway, the Showa era, according to wikipedia, was from 1926-1989. (CCW)
    昭 (shining or Showa era) + 和 (peace or  Japan) = 昭和 (Showa Era)
    Star-16Star-16
昭和 ( しょわ )
    nickname of Emperor Hirohito - from which the Era got its name. (CCW)
    昭 (shining or Showa era) + 和 (peace or  Japan) = 昭和 (Hirohitos nickname)
    Star-16Star-16

So you can say, "I can hang nine round donuts on the HOOK."

Number: 174
忍 hide or endure
Star-16Star-16
7 strokes
JERK, PN
刃 (blade) + 心 (bottomheart)

ONYOMI: NIN

The NINJA has to hide well and endure discomfort with a steady heart , in order to successfully stab his target with his blade.

KUNYOMI:

しの*ぶ
    A very old word - from feudal times - not used anymore. It means "to endure or bear," but is usually used only in the context of bearing shame or disgrace. The ninja connection of this kanji lies in the SECOND meaning , which is restricted to this one idiom: 人目を忍ぶ　（ひとめをしのぶ）, meaning, to do secretly , or to do without being seen.
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

忍者 ( にんじゃ )
    its a -- Quick, look behind you!!!!!!!!!!!!!
    忍 (hide or endure) + 者 (professional) = 忍者 (NINJA!!!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
忍耐 ( にんたい )
    patience, forbearance -basically it is a more formal version of 我慢　（がまん）. However, 我慢 can be used in the active sense of "keep doing what youre doing, keep rolling that rock up the hill, dont quit." Whereas, 忍耐 has more a passive nuance - "Continue doing nothing, fight the urge to counter-attack or snap back." (NP)
    忍 (hide or endure) + 耐 (withstand) = 忍耐 (forbear, endure)
    - zero stars! -

USED IN:

    認

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
刃 	blade 	SWORD 	刀
丸 	round 	HOOK 	Hook

Blade comes from the SWORD radical, which makes sense.

Round comes from 9, which has a HOOK on the right side. (the right side of blade turns outwards).

So you can say, "I can hang nine round donuts on the HOOK."

Number: 198
京 capital
Star-16Star-16Star-16
8 strokes
BETA, PN
Lid (beret) + 口 (mouth or small box radical) + 小 (small size)

ONYOMI: KYOU

TODAY (今日= KYOU) I am going to the capital.

The fashion in the capital city is, to wear a beret, with a tiny soul patch below your mouth.

DESCRIPTION:BOOBOO:This means capital city of Japan, As opposed to 都 which means capital city in the sense of Hollywood is the film capital or Paris is the art capital or San Francisco is the bear capital.
JUKUGO:

東京 ( とうきょう )
    Tokyo
    東 (east) + 京 (capital) = 東京 (Tokyo)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
東京都 ( とうきょうと )
    Tokyo -to. Tokyo is the capital of Japan, so　it has "-to" on the end of it. Most cities have a 市（し） instead. And most prefectures have a 県 (けん） instead. If you think thats confusing, look at Washington DC - its not a state, but its not a city. Its a "district." Huh?
    東­京 (Tokyo) + 都 (major city) = 東京都 (capital city)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
京都 ( きょうと )
    Kyoto (the former capital!)
    京 (capital) + 都 (major city) = 京都 (Kyoto (the former capital!))
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    涼
    景
    就

    to show or indicate.But you cant say Ill show you my wang. Why? One, in that case , youre supposed to use miseru instead, and two, you dont have a wang, you lost it in the war.

    示す is more like "Studies indicate a link between yo mama and trench-mouth." Or "History shows again and again how nature points out the folly of man."
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

展示会 ( てんじかい )
    an exhibition or trade-show (International Plumbing Equipment Expo 2010!)
    展 (exhibit) + 示 (show) + 会 (big meeting) = 展示会 (trade-show)
    Star-16Star-16
指示 ( しじ )
    instructions　ー not like instructions from your boss, but like the instruction manual you get with your new vacuum cleaner.
    指 (finger or point at) + 示 (show) = 指示 (instructions　)
    Star-16

Number: 225
用 utilize
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
5 strokes
Inside (George Michaels Moustache) + 干 (dry out)

ONYOMI: YOU

If you want to communicate between Alpine peaks, you should utilize YODELING.

George Michael utilized a blowdryer to dry out his moustache.

DESCRIPTION: literally 用 means "utilize", but it has a more sinister meaning: only. As in, men only or Japanese only.

KUNYOMI:

もち＊いる
    To use. (More formal scientific than つかう） As in, "Please use this pencil to complete the test. (NP)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

用事 ( ようじ )
    errands, chores, stuff to do. "Id love to come to see your performance piece, buttttt Ive got 用事。”
    用 (utilize) + 事 (action or  incident) = 用事 (errands)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
XXX 用 (XXX よう )
    SUFFIX meaning, only XXX can use this water fountain. (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
用意 する ( ようい する)
    get set - basically it means the same as 準備 , but the nuance is a bit more abstract. : If you’re getting prepared mentally , that’s 準備(じゅんび） . If you’re arranging stuff over the phone, use 用意 . The ‘Get set!’ in ‘Get ready! Get set! Go!’ is 用意 .
    用 (utilize) + 意 (meaning) = 用意 (get set！！)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
利用 する ( りよう する)
    to utilize. Usually used in the sense of, Only students or Japanese or Scientologists can utilize this swimming pool.　
    利 (handy) + 用 (utilize) = 利用 (utilize)
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 246
士 samurai radical
Star-16Star-16Star-16
3 strokes
PK, SUF, BETA, STRONG
(samurai radical)
土 (earth)

ONYOMI: SHI

SHEs harrier than most male samurai. Ironic? Maybe. Sexy, you bet.

This is basically earth (土), but instead of the bottom stroke being long, the top stroke is long.

You can think of it like this: The bottom stroke of earth (土 ) is longer, because the bottom stroke represents the horizon, extending a million miles in each direction.

Whereas, in Samurai,(士) the top stroke is longer, because hes angry and has both arms extended to cut you with his swords, because you rose up against the unjust feudal system. Or whatever. I just am not feeling those guys.

DESCRIPTION: The actual kanji for samurai is 侍.

But in school, all the teachers tell you that 士　means samurai, so what the fuck. So, this is the samurai radical.

It is never used by itself, but it means "violent or socially respected job."
JUKUGO:

兵士 ( へいし )
    infantryman, low-ranking soldier
    兵 (soldier) + 士 (samurai radical) = 兵士 (infantryman, low-ranking soldier)
    Star-16Star-16
武士 ( ぶし )
    White kids say samurai, but real Japanese usually say ぶし. It can also be used to refer to the whole social class, as in　武士精神 （ぶしせいしん = samruai spirit) or　武士道 （ぶしどう = the honor-code of the samurai)
    武 (military) + 士 (samurai radical) = 武士 (samurai)
    Star-16Star-16
力士 ( りきし )
    Sumo rassler (FP)
    力 (strong) + 士 (samurai radical) = 力士 (Sumo rassler)
    Star-16Star-16
消防士 ( しょうぼうし )
    firefighter
    消 (erase) + 防 (ward off) + 士 (samurai radical) = 消防士 (firefighter)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
土 	earth 	BOTTOM LINE LONGER 	
士 	samurai radical 	TOP LINE LONGER

But kindness ORIGINATES in the heart.

    結 (bind) + 婚 (marriage) = 結婚 (to marry)

    result

    Star-16Star-16Star-16
結構 です。 ( けっこう です。)
    this has 3 meanings, each used just as often as the others .

    1)literally, "OK."

    2) "No thank you" (just like American women, Japanese people use Thats ok to mean No.!)

    3) "Very much" : You often hear people saying, "Kekkou atsui ne!" ("Its very hot today, eh?") (1 or 2 KANA, JERK)
    結 (bind) + 構 (set up or care about) = 結構 (ok or no thanks or very)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 256
者 professional
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
8 strokes
COCK, STRONG
Dizzy (dizzy) + 日 (sun, day)

ONYOMI: SHA

The professional SHALL work all day until they get dizzy!

DESCRIPTION: COCK - when its used with the ON-yomi, it means professional, but when its used with the KUN-yomi, it just means person.

What makes it even more fucked: theres no way to guess which is which. Because theyre grammatically identical! (both are suffixes)

Even more fucked: the pronunciation of the person meaning of 者 is the same as the word for thing. （物） This kanji is just incredibly retarded.

STRONG RADICAL: almost all kanji which incorporate this radical are pronounced SHO. Even though its own kunyomi is SHA!!!

Just keeps getting worse, dont it?!?

KUNYOMI:

( xxx ) もの
    person (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

若者 ( わかもの )
    young person - example of the kunyomi (もの） suffix (KUNKUN)
    若 (young) + 者 (professional) = 若者 (young person)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
記者 ( きしゃ )
    reporter
    記 (diary) + 者 (professional) = 記者 (reporter)
    Star-16Star-16
ばか者 ( ばかもの )
    dumb person - example of the kunyomi (もの) suffix. (KUNKUN)
    Star-16Star-16
科学者 ( かがくしゃ )
    scientist
    科­学 (science) + 者 (professional) = 科学者 (scientist)
    Star-16Star-16
芸者 ( げいしゃ )
    what Asian chicks in college get mad about
    芸 (art) + 者 (professional) = 芸者 (geisha)
    Star-16

Number: 264
焦 char or scorch
Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
Turkey (turkey) + 火 (firebottom)

ONYOMI: SHOU

Dont SHOW off your cooking, that roast turkey is pretty clearly scorched in the fire.

KUNYOMI:

( を ) こ＊がす
    to char or scortch. Like char-broiled beef. Also, often used with hot, passionate emotions: burning with the fiiiire of looooooveeeee!!!!!!!!!!!!
    Star-16Star-16
( が ) こ＊げる
    it gets scorched
    Star-16Star-16
( が ) あせ＊る
    to be in a hurry, impatient (KANA)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
無 	without 	NO HEAD 	
焦 	char or scorch 	HEAD 	

OK,without (無) is basically like the "scorch" kanji ( 焦）　but WITHOUT the little line that sticks up in the center.

As usual, well call the sticky-uppy line a head.

So you can say,

The top of WITHOUT is flat, because its WITHOUT a HEAD.

Or, alternatively, "Youre scorching my HEAD!!!"


Number: 265
無 without
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
PRE, SUF
Turkey (turkey) + 火 (firebottom)

ONYOMI: MU

you cant say MOO without a cow!

OK, this is basically like "scorch" kanji ( 焦）　but WITHOUT the little head in the center: The top of 無 is flat, WITHOUT a head.

DESCRIPTION: This is the kanji for ない, although it is seldom used anymore.

KUNYOMI:

( ｘｘｘ ) な＊い
    SUFFIX which turns the previous word into a negative. 金＝money。 金無い＝ no money. (KANA)
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

    free (not like Martin Luther King, I mean free like a free magazine full of articles on how to become a stripper)

    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    Defense attorney (BOOBOO: its often translated as lawyer, but べんごし usually handle criminal cases - murder, arson, etc. Lawsuits or legal procedures related to your visa are either handled by a sort of freelance bureaucrat or notary or by the mob. )
    弁 (dialect) + 護 (defend) + 士 (samurai radical) = 弁護士 (Defense attorney)
    Star-16Star-16
保護 する ( ほご する)
    conserve, protect - only used in the literal sense. (BOOBOO: conservative person is　保守的な　（ほしゅてきな）　人)

JUKUGO:

中止 された ( ちゅうし された)
    (temporarily) stopped or (permanently) canceled. This is a word youd hear in an announcement. You wouldnt say to your friend, "Im going to 中止 watching TV for a week." (NP)
    中 (middle) + 止 (stop) = 中止 (stop or cancel)
    Star-16Star-16
痛み止め ( いたみどめ )
    pain-killer, like aspirin. (BOOBOO: not anaesthetic, which is 麻酔（ますい） )

Number: 282
是 fer shure

SIDEKICK

JUKUGO:

是非 ( ぜひ )
    this has 2 meanings:

    1) in casual conversation, starting a sentence with zehi means, Absolutely! Ill get it done by hook or by crook! - also, youll hear ぜひおねがいします！ a lot, which means Thanks in advance for this favor. . . . .

    2) the propriety or morality of a certain course of action ( the kanji themselves translate to right + injustice). (1 or 2 KANA)
    是 (fer shure) + 非 (injustice or mistake) = 是非 (absolutely!)

Number: 284
証 proof
Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
言 (say) + 正 (correct)

ONYOMI: SHOU

SHOW me the PROOF!

The cop said, "If you can talk to me and show me correct proof , youre good to go. "

KUNYOMI:

あかし
    evidence, testimony . . .: somewhere in between 証明（しょうめい: proof）　and 証拠　（しょうこ: phsyical evidence）. Youd typically use 証 when youre talking about evidence of god such as miracles. Or youd challenge someone "You say youre honest and give to charity, but do you have any evidence of this?" Unlike 証拠、　証　does not have to be physical, it can be verbal.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

運転免許証 ( うんてん めんきょしょう )
    drivers license
    運­転 (drive a vehicle) + 免­許 (an exemption from something, or a license to do something. (i.e. drivers license: 運転免許証 (うんてん　めんきょ　しょう）) + 証 (proof) = 運転免許証 (drivers license)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
証拠 ( しょうこ )
    physical evidence, such as a footprint, or "This green tap-water is evidence of pollution." Also this is the word one uses about evidence at trials, not 証. (FP, NP)
    証 (proof) + 拠 (evidence which is the basis for a judgment) = 証拠 (physical evidence)
    Star-16Star-16
証明書 ( しょうめいしょ )
    a legal document certifying something: that youre married, that you have a job, that you paid tax, that you ...
    証 (proof) + 明 (bright) + 書 (write) = 証明書 (legal certification)
    Star-16

    the reason for something

    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    excuse, as in, But my moms not fat, shes just big-boned. (actually, she IS, often, but not in the way you meant it)
    言 (say) + 訳 (reason or translation) = 言い訳 (excuse)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

通訳 ( つうやく )

    通 (pass) + 訳 (reason or translation) = 通訳 (simultaneous translation)

    片 (fragment) + 手 (hand) = 片手 (one-handed)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
手 	hand 	bottom swings LEFT 	
毛 	fur 	bottom swings RIGHT 	

The bottom of hand bends to the left, because the leper LEFT his hand back at the motel.

Much to the surprise of your mother, the maid.

The bottom of fur bends more considerably to the RIGHT, because you have to wear the RIGHT　fur if you are going to impress people at the pimp show or opera.

    推 (infer) + 定 (plan) = 推定 (estimate)
    Star-16
推測 する ( すいそく する)
    speculate. Kind of formal: "Its too early to speculate about the economy." "Scientists speculate that..." (NP)
    推 (infer) + 測 (scientific measurment) = 推測 (speculate.)
    Star-16
推理 ( すいり )
    deductive reasoning, inference.
    推 (infer) + 理 (reason) = 推理 (deductive reasoning, inference.)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
推 	infer 	HAND 	手
唯 	sole or only 	MOUTH 	口
稚 	childish 	WHEAT 	Wheat
維 	upkeep 	STRING 	糸

Detectives infer the crooks identity based on his HAND-prints.

You got only one MOUTH.

Farmers pick the most childish of WHEAT: the seeds.

STRING helps me keep the turkey in the yard.

    the little cat in all the shop windows. Its kind of a weird phenomenon if you think about it: One paw is up, beckoning customers to come in, like "Come on in, guy! I like your style!" But the other paw clutches a gold coin, usually marked 10,000,000 yen. Like "OK, J or K about valuing you. I just want your money." (CCW)
    招 (beckon) + 猫 (cat) = 招き猫 (shop-window cat)

Your friend beckons you by waving her SWORD over her head and hence, OVER HER MOUTH, all, "hey over here!" style.

    哲­学 (philosophy (adj.: 哲学的な、てつがくてきな）) + 者 (professional) = 哲学者 (philosopher)
    Star-16

Number: 329

ILL PAIR

    near - both physically, in time, and metaphorically, as in Your left boob is so stretched, its nearly a banana.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
ちか＊く
    close to
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

最近 ( さいきん )
    recently
    最 (most) + 近 (near) = 最近 (recently)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
近所 ( きんじょ )
    in this neighborhood, around here- (BOOBOO: 近所 is strictly relative to where you are standing at the time. You cant say Shibuya is a neighborhood in tokyo, - in that case, you have to use MACHI(町)。)
    近 (near) + 所 (area attribute) = 近所 (around here)
    Star-16Star-16
に or が 近付く (に or が ちかづく )
    to draw close to a physical destination or a goal. (1 or 2 KANA)

    Star-16Star-16
に 近寄る (に ちかよる )
    to get close to, to approach.(usually used in the negative, on warning signs: danger! keep out! danger! high voltage! 近寄るな!)

Number: 330
辺 around here or around that time
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
5 strokes
PN, SOLO, ILL PAIR
Moving (motion) + 刀 (sword)

ONYOMI: HEN

I saw a HEN moving around here with a sword!! (it was making Human MacNuggets!)

DESCRIPTION: COCK - because it is really 3 words, all of which mean the same exact same thing but are pronounced differently, and have different grammar. (Actually, the different grammar is a blessing in disguise, because it cues you which pronunciation to use).

KUNYOMI:

あた＊り
    this neighborhood, the vicinity (as opposed to far away or another hood)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
( この ) へん ( に )
    one thing which is around here somewhere!!
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
( ｘｘｘ ) べ ( に )
    BE is a SUFFIX, which can be put after any noun, meaning in the vicinity of: the ocean, the university, the table, etc. You can tell be and hen (above) apart because be always comes after a proper noun- its a SUFFIX. (SUF)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
近 	near 	AXE 	斤
辺 	around here or around that time 	SWORD 	刀

He came near with an AXE,

but at that time I had a SWORD to counter-attack.

迫 press upon

    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 333
達 plural or delivery
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
SUF, BETA, JERK
Moving (motion) + 幸 (luck, happiness)

ONYOMI: TATSU or  TACHI

I was TAUGHT TO use plurals correctly, therefore I am TOUCHY when people fuck them up.

Its considered happy to move in pairs because you have a friend.

DESCRIPTION: JERK: Normally, this means "the delivery arrives" but half the time means "plural." There is no easy way to tell which it means.
JUKUGO:

友達 ( ともだち )
    friend
    友 (friend) + 達 (plural or delivery) = 友達 (friend)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
私達 ( わたしたち )
    us (1 or 2 KANA)
    私 (me or private) + 達 (plural or delivery) = 私達 (us)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
XXX 達 (XXX たち )
    SUFFIX, meaning "more than one of XXX."But unlike English, you cant pluralize just any word.

    In fact 90% of the time youll see 達, its in one of these 3 situations: 1) 仲間達：なかまたち：　the group of friends. 2) 人達：ひとたち： people, and 3) 子供達：こどもたち： the children. (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
配達 する ( はいたつ する)
    to deliver. Used about business - used when money changes hands. Deliver by truck or UPS or FEDEX.
    配 (distribute) + 達 (plural or delivery) = 配達 (deliver)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
達 	plural or delivery 	HAPPY 	幸
運 	carry or luck 	SOLDIERS 	軍
連 	take with or inform of 	CAR 	車

Im HAPPY to have plural friends.

I need to carry SOLDIERS to the battle,

So Ill take them with me in my CAR.

Number: 339
本 book or the real
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
5 strokes
PN, JERK, SYMBOLIC
木 (tree) + 一 (one or line radical)

ONYOMI: HON

本 is tree (木) plus one line. You can think of that extra line as the real, uh. . .hold on. . .. uh, the ground! The real estate the tree is growing in!

Or, you can think of the line as a page of a book (made from a tree).

Or you can just go home and take a bath. I dont care.

DESCRIPTION: JERK RADICAL: by itself, it means book, but most of the jukugo with the 本 kanji have to do with foundation.

KUNYOMI:

ほん
    book (LAZY)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

本当 に ( ほんとう に)
    for realz.
    本 (book or the real) + 当 (hit the target) = 本当 (for realz.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
ｘｘｘ 本 (ｘｘｘ ほん )
    used for counting. Ippon is one book. Psyche! ISSATSU (一冊) is one book, ippon is one cylindrical object. Makes sense if you imagine that back when Chinese sages were inventing kanji, books were written on scrolls and shit。

    Pronounced like this: 1: いっぽん、２： にほん、　３：　さんぼん、　etc. (COUNTER)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
本音 ( ほんね )
    ones real feelings, as opposed to 建前　（たてまえ）. You know, the 2 faces that only Japanese people have, as if no one else in the world would dream of being so false, and all that bullshit. (FP, CCW)
    本 (book or the real) + 音 (sound) = 本音 (ones real feelings)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
本物 ( ほんもの )
    the real thing, not a counterfeit. (KUNKUN)
    本 (book or the real) + 物 (animal or thing) = 本物 (the real thing, not a counterfeit.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
本来 ( ほんらい )
    originally, essentially , primairlyー Emphasizes the historical roots. Originally the EPA was supposed to protect the environment, but nowadays its protecting the polluters!
    本 (book or the real) + 来 (come or future) = 本来 (originally)
    Star-16Star-16
本 ｘｘｘ ( ほん ｘｘｘ)
    PREFIX meaning, the real xxx.

    For example, 本人 means in person (I saw Billy Idol in person at the Costco!). (PRE)
    Star-16Star-16

USED IN:

    体



Number: 340

    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    guarantee

    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    politically or morally conservative. (NEO)
    保 (guarantee or maintain ) + 守 (protect) + 主­義 (SUFFIX meaning ism. As in capitalism, communism, materialism, and a Japanese grindcore band called intestine baalism. ) = 保守主義 (conservative)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    insurance
    保 (guarantee or maintain ) + 険 (steep) = 保険 (insurance)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
保存 ( ほぞん )
    conserve (natural resources, the environment, traditional morals, our dwindling fuel supply, etc.) - political conservatives are 保存主義(ほぞんしゅぎ)
    保 (guarantee or maintain ) + 存 (be aware of) = 保存 (conserve)
    Star-16Star-16
健康保険 ( けんこうほけん )
    health insurance
    健­康 (health) + 保­険 (insurance) = 健康保険 (health insurance)
    Star-16Star-16
面目を保つ ( めんぼくをたもつ )
    to save face (opposite: 面目を失う　（めんぼくをうしなう）） (CCW)
    面 (front surface or face) + 目 (eye) + 保 (guarantee or maintain ) = 面目を保つ (save face)
    Star-16
保護 する ( ほご する)
    conserve, protect - only used in the literal sense. (BOOBOO: conservative person is　保守的な　（ほしゅてきな）　人)
    保 (guarantee or maintain ) + 護 (defend) = 保護 (conserve, protect)
    Star-16
保証人 ( ほしょうにん )
    a guarantor. This may not sound like a useful word to know, but if you ever come to Nippon, youll need a Japanese guarantor. For pretty much everything- getting an apartment, a visa, etc. Usually its your boss. So if you lose your job, your boss can kick you out of your house AND the country. Its a sort of share-cropper system!
    保­証 (guarantee) + 人 (person) = 保証人 (a guarantor)
    Star-16

Number: 380
愁 sorrow
Star-16
13 strokes
DUPE
秋 (fall) (Same-ON) + 心 (bottomheart)

ONYOMI: SHUU

Your SHOES are so wack it fills me with sorrow.

When the season turns to fall, my heart is always full of sorrow.

KUNYOMI:

うれ*い
    melancholy- sorrowful - but more subtle than the OTHER うれい　（憂い）。 Regular urei is like a homeless guy that is obviously suffering and you can see why. 愁い is like a elegant woman in a kimono going to a temple and carrying with her a subtle poetic aura of sadness. Older Japanese guys go for this.
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

哀愁 ( あいしゅう )
    an archaic, literary word meaning, "melancholy, pathos, grief." (used about a novel, song, movie, or tone of voice, but not about a person). (NP)
    哀 (pitiful) + 愁 (sorrow) = 哀愁 (melancholy)
    Star-16
郷愁 ( きょうしゅう )
    literary word for nostalgia (BOOBOO: most people just say 懐かしい　（なつかしい！）) (NP)
    郷 (ones hometown) + 愁 (sorrow) = 郷愁 (nostalgia)
    - zero stars! -

Number: 382
未 not yet
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
5 strokes
木 (tree) + 一 (one or line radical)

ONYOMI: MI

Im not yet the perfect ME.

未 is basically 末, but with a SHORTER upper stroke. . HOW TO TELL THEM APART;

未-tip - SHORT UPPER BRANCH on the tree

末 - not yet - LONG UPPER BRANCH on the tree

The MADA tree, the extra branch has not yet fully grown, thats why it is shorter than the middle one.

The SUE tree, however, the extra branch has grown ALL THE WAY TO THE TIP, which is why its LONGER than the middle one.

    not yet (1 or 2 KANA)

The motion of the rice perplexed me until I figured out it was actually a BOWL of maggots!

DESCRIPTION:This word is wonderful because all of its jukugo correspond neatly to English words, and are not irritating synonyms of almost-identical Japanese words.

KUNYOMI:

( に ) まよ*う
    to be paralyzed because you are unable to choose. (i.e. when shopping, or when you are lost and cant decide which street to take)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

道に迷う ( みちにまよう )
    get lost.
    道 (street) + 迷 (perplexed) = 道に迷う (get lost.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
迷子 ( まいご )
    lost child (FP)
    迷 (perplexed) + 子 (child) = 迷子 (lost child)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
迷路 ( めいろ )
    maze
    迷 (perplexed) + 路 (road) = 迷路 (maze)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
迷 	perplexed 	RICE (2 dots!!) 	米
述 	refer to 	ONE DOT 	

You get perplexed by RICE, so you refer to ONE DOT to comparison:

"OK, if its bigger than this dot, then it must not be rice."

    "Tony is tai hen!" , for instance, could mean:

    a) I feel sorry for Tony because his job sucks and his girl is cheating.

    b) Tony is a really scary, mean person.　
    大 (big) + 変 (change) = 大変 (thats terrible!)

奇妙 な ( きみょう な)
    weird - but more broad than the related term 妙. 奇妙 means unusual and absurd - a street-person wearing a duck as a hat is 奇妙.

好奇心 ( こうきしん )
    curiosity

    BOOBOO: if you want to say youre curious about a specific thing, youd use 興味　（きょうみ） instead.

    好奇心 usually means "curiosity-in-general": 　you have an inquiring personality, or a gaze of curiosity on your face. Youd never say, "Oh, you play in a band? 好奇心ある！”
    好 (like) + 奇 (strange) + 心 (heart) = 好奇心 (curiosity)

    of course

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
痴漢 ( ちかん )
    Usually 漢 means Chinese: its used in a lot of obscure words (Chinese dictionary, Chinese herbal medicine, Chinese classical literature, etc.)

    HOWEVER - aside from 漢字 - the only time 漢 is really used in daily life is here: 痴漢, meaning a guy who molests or gropes women on crowded trains.

    So the literal reading is: sick Chinese !WTF??? (FR, 1 or 2 KANA)
    痴 (molester) + 漢 (Chinese) = 痴漢 (train pervert)

    to criticize someone for no reason, just to nag at them.

    Star-16
困難 ( こんなん )
    a hardship, big trouble. Not like "Oh, If I fail this test, Im going to be in big trouble!" こんなん is more like an ongoing hardship, like your parents died when you were young and you had to put yourself through school while working 20 hours a week washing dishes. Also often used in this phrase: 困難の時代 (troubled times) (NP)
    困 (trouble) + 難 (difficult) = 困難 (hardship)
    Star-16

Opium (opium) (Same-ON) + 日 (sun, day)

KUNYOMI:

( で ) く＊らす
    This doesnt correspond to any English word. Maybe the closest phrase is, "To lead ones life."

    Homeless people, retirees, and rich divorcees all 暮らす even though they dont 稼ぐ.

    It means "to live in a place" as well as "to do all ones daily junk (eating, sleeping, hanging out)." 暮らす is usually used in sentences like, "over 30,000 people are living in the city." or "Live on $20 a day," or "She had an easy or hard life."
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 430
恩 kindness
Star-16Star-16
10 strokes
因 (origin) + 心 (bottomheart)

ONYOMI: ON

The origin of kindness is ON the heart.

KUNYOMI:

おん
    gratitude. Unlike the related words 恩恵　（おんけい） and 義理 (ぎり）, 恩 means that you really WANT to do something nice, to give back to the person youre grateful to. Also, unlike 義理、恩 doesnt imply that you owe them a specific favor. Often, 恩 is used like, "Everyone else gave up on me, told me I was a juvenile delinquent, that Id amount to nothing. That teacher was the only one who believed in me, who kept encouraging me no matter how many times I fucked up. とても恩がある。"
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

恩恵 ( おんけい )
    favor. Unlike the very personal "恩", giving and receiving 恩恵 is a more businesslike form of gratitude: 恩恵を受ける means "to recieve a favor." A sort of Ill-scratch-your-back-if-you-scratch-mine practicality.
    恩 (kindness) + 恵 (do a favor) = 恩恵 (favor)
    Star-16
恩知らず ( おんしらず )
    ｉｎｇｒａｔｅ (literally, unaware of gratitude.)
    恩 (kindness) + 知 (know) = 恩知らず (ingrate)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
恵 	do a favor 	TNT plunger 	Tntplunger
恩 	kindness 	ORIGINATES 	因
志 	intention, volition 	SAMURAI 	士

You do a favor to Wile E. Coyote by giving him a TNT PLUNGER,
But kindness ORIGINATES in the heart.
She has the intention of becoming a SAMURAI.

Number: 432
困 trouble

    to be in trouble. . . .not exactly. It doesnt mean punishment like Youre in trouble! means in English. Its not like your teacher yelling at you. If youre late and cant find your shoes, thats こまった. If youre lost, thats こまった. If you forgot your password for ratemycheneyfanfiction.org, thats . . . actually youre better off, probably. (BOOBOO)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

困難 ( こんなん )
    a hardship, big trouble. Not like "Oh, If I fail this test, Im going to be in big trouble!" こんなん is more like an ongoing hardship, like your parents died when you were young and you had to put yourself through school while working 20 hours a week washing dishes. Also often used in this phrase: 困難の時代 (troubled times) (NP)
    困 (trouble) + 難 (difficult) = 困難 (hardship)
    Star-16

    a coffee-shop. These are really popular because Japanese dont invite people over to their homes very often - they meet at the coffee-shop. This is fairly polite example to point to when a Japanese asks you, "Do foreigners really think were a cold people?" BOOBOO: most Japanese dont say きっさてん。 they just say 喫茶、(きっさ)。
    喫 (enjoy a drink and a smoke) + 茶 (tea) + 店 (shop) = 喫茶店 (coffe-shop)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
喫煙 ( きつえん )
    the act of smoking. Youll see this on signs a lot, meaning this is the smoking section. (NP)
    喫 (enjoy a drink and a smoke) + 煙 (smoky) = 喫煙 (smoking)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
暇 	free time 	DAY 	日
喫 	enjoy a drink and a smoke 	MOUTH 	口
潔 	honorable 	WATER 	水
御 	the honorific "o" 	GO 	行

Im free TODAY, to enjoy a drink with my MOUTH.

Im honorable so Ill share my WATER .

As for 御, it is easy because the left radical means GO in English, and its pronounced GO!!!
USED IN:

    潔
