Number: 459
害 damage
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
10 strokes
BETA
Crown (crown) + 主 (master or mainly) + 口 (mouth or small box radical)

ONYOMI: GAI

That GUY punched the master right in the fucking mouth, damaging his crown in the process.
JUKUGO:

公害 ( こうがい )
    pollution. Has a more broad meaning than the related word 汚染（おせん）。 Not just dirty smoggy air, but also noise pollution, the annoyance of someone talking on a cellphone on a train, and 情報公害　（じょうほうこうがい）: "ad pollution" - the inescapable advertisements one sees everywhere. BOOBOO:If you want to say "environmental pollution," you have to use 汚染、　not 公害。
    公 (public) + 害 (damage) = 公害 (pollution.)
    Star-16Star-16
被害 ( ひがい )
    damage (to property) or casualties (human): used about earthquakes, wars, and crimes.
    被 (get injured) + 害 (damage) = 被害 (casualties)
    Star-16Star-16
被害者 ( ひがいしゃ )
    victim (NP)
    被­害 (damage (to property) or casualties (human): used about earthquakes, wars, and crimes. ) + 者 (professional) = 被害者 (victim)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical

害 	damage 	MOUTH 	口

Sugar damages your mouth, but the addict eats it EVERY day.

Number: 468
情 emotion
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

なさ＊け
    mercy (usually used in the negative!)
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

感情 ( かんじょう )
    a feeling, an emotion
    感 (feeling) + 情 (emotion) = 感情 (a feeling, an emotion)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
事情 ( じじょう )
    circumstances. A euphemism for bad situation: crushing debt, mother is a prostitute, etc, in trouble with the mob, etc.

    彼女、事情がありそうね。 (She looks like she comes from Circumstances, doesnt she?)

    事情 also differs from other situation words because it emphasizes the circumstances behind a persons actions. (i.e. the boss says, You were late to work again, but if you explain your situation, I might not punish you.)
    事 (action or  incident) + 情 (emotion) = 事情 (circumstances)
    Star-16Star-16
愛情 ( あいじょう )
    affection : more than friendship and less than love.
    愛 (love) + 情 (emotion) = 愛情 (affection : more than friendship and less than love.)
    Star-16
表情 ( ひょうじょう )
    facial expression - although most people say "XXXの顔をした”　（ｘｘｘのかおをした）, meaning "She made an xxx-face."
    表 (express) + 情 (emotion) = 表情 (facial expression)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
朱 	vermilion 	PENIS ON THE BOTTOM 	
失 	miss out on 	HEAD but NO PENIS 	
矢 	arrow 	NO HEAD 	

Vermillion has a dick between its legs (think of the bright red veins in a dick). Arrow and Miss dont have anything down there.

HOW TO TELL ARROW AND MISS APART: "失" has a little line sticking up at the top, which well call a HEAD. 矢has no head.

So you can say, "I MISS getting HEAD from your uncle ever since he got BEHEADED BY AN ARROW."
USED IN:

    株



Number: 475
株 share, stock

10 strokes

JUKUGO:

株式 ( かぶしき )
    This is the word used in financial terms about stocks IN GENERAL - IPO or go public or stock amoritization and the like (NP)
    株 (share, stock) + 式 (ritual) = 株式 (stocks)
    Star-16Star-16
株式会社 ( かぶしきがいしゃ )
    a corporation - youll usually see this word after the company name on their front window. DAMAGE, INC. = DAMAGE,株式会社; 　MURDER, INCORPORATED = MURDER株式会社。
    株­式 (This is the word used in financial terms about stocks IN GENERAL - IPO or go public or stock amoritization and the like) + 会­社 (company) = 株式会社 (a corporation)
    Star-16Star-16
株式市場 ( かぶしき いちば )
    株式（stocks)＋地場(marketplace)＝the stock market！ (NEO, FP)
    株­式 (This is the word used in financial terms about stocks IN GENERAL - IPO or go public or stock amoritization and the like) + 市 (small city) + 場 (place) = 株式市場 (stock market)
    Star-16

Number: 484
海 ocean
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
9 strokes
水 (waterleft) + 毎 (every)

ONYOMI: KAI

I flew a giant KITE all the way across the ocean!

KUNYOMI:

うみ
    ocean
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

海岸 ( かいがん )
    the coast OR the beach! Unlike 浜辺 or 浜, 海岸 has a scientific meaning: the coastline, (regardless of if theres sand or not). Youll see 海岸 on maps or geography books. The useage of 海岸 is odd, even for Japanese. Where Americans will just say, "Lets go to the beach!", Japanese might suggest to their pals, "海へ行こう！”（lets go to the ocean!) but ONLY ONCE THEY WERE ALREADY THERE, then they might specifically suggest going to the 海岸 - as opposed to other things to do by the sea. Weird!　
    海 (ocean) + 岸 (shore) = 海岸 (coast or beach)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
海外 ( かいがい )
    accross the sea - foreign countries, basically.
    海 (ocean) + 外 (outside) = 海外 (foreign countries)
    Star-16Star-16
海軍 ( かいぐん )
    in the kaiiiigun, you can sail the seven seeeeas, in the kaiiiigun, you can put yourself at eeeeease...
    海 (ocean) + 軍 (army) = 海軍 (navy)
    Star-16
海底 ( かいてい )
    bottom of the ocean
    海 (ocean) + 底 (bottom) = 海底 (bottom of the ocean)
    - zero stars! -

    the social, everyday world - more poetic than 世界。 Used in dramatic declarations like, "Im sick of this fuckin world!" "I dont care about this life!" "Poor Kurt Cobain, he was just too sensitive for this cruel world!" Also, usually implies JUST Japanese society.
    世 (society) + 中 (middle) = 世の中 (the world)

    (temporarily) stopped or (permanently) canceled. This is a word youd hear in an announcement. You wouldnt say to your friend, "Im going to 中止 watching TV for a week." (NP)
    中 (middle) + 止 (stop) = 中止 (stop or cancel)
    Star-16Star-16

    in the middle of doing XXX.

    XXX is always a noun: 電話中　（電話中）means Im on the phone right now! (SUF)

    to be affiliated with, (the research hospital is affiliated with Cambridge University), to be a member of (Im a member of the Juggalo quilting club)

    attached - i.e. an institute attached to a certain university. Or, included, as in use the gloves included with the hair-bleach kit. Attachments - such as vacuum cleaner attachments or PC peripherals are also 付属.

Number: 504
所 area or attribute
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
8 strokes
戸 (door) + 斤 (axe)

ONYOMI: SHO

If you go to a bachelors area, you can Smell His Odors.

Go to the place where they live, and knock down the front door with an axe.

KUNYOMI:

ところ
    3 meanings.
    1= area, place
    2= attribute. 'Hes got a stupid tokoro.' means 'Hes stupid.'
    3= a place in time. "Ima no tokoro" means "ima, SoreDOkoro de wa nai!" means, We dont have time for your bullshit right now.
    Basically meanings ２ and 3 are purely rhetorical - you can delete them from the sentence and the meaning stays the same. (1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

場所 ( ばしょ )
    place, like a parking lot. Also space, as in, your moms cant ride in my new van because theres not enough space.

    This is by far the most popular word to use these kanji, so its too bad the pronunciation is messed up: 場 uses kun, but 所 uses onyomi. Assholes. (KUN ON)
    場 (place) + 所 (area or attribute) = 場所 (place)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
住所 ( じゅうしょ )
    address
    住 (dwell) + 所 (area or attribute) = 住所 (address)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
長所 ( ちょうしょ )
    strong point, as opposed to weak point. Can be used about people (his 長所 is his courage, her 長所 is her brain) or machines (The strong point of this PC is its long battery-life)
    長 (long or boss) + 所 (area or attribute) = 長所 (good point)
    Star-16Star-16
短所 ( たんしょ )
    weak point, flaw
    短 (short) + 所 (area or attribute) = 短所 (flaw )
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 522
境 border
Star-16Star-16Star-16
14 strokes
土 (earth) + 立 (stand up) + 見 (look)

ONYOMI: KYOU

as in, "Todays ( = 今日, pronounced KYOU) border will vanish tomorrow, when The Man starts his next war." Ooh, political!!

If you stand on the earth over there, you can see all the way to the border

KUNYOMI:

さかい
    boundary - can be used with countries OR property lines of 2 pieces of land. Usually used when talking about crossing a boundary, or being within the boundary.
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

環境 ( かんきょう )
    environment (like English, this is not limited to nature. A bad kid can be a "product of his environment.")
    環 (environment) + 境 (border) = 環境 (environment)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
国境 ( こっきょう )
    national border
    国 (country) + (border) = 国境 (national border)
    Star-16Star-16
境界 ( きょうかい )
    means border or boundary of property (80% the same usage as さかい　（境） , but a bit more formal).

    BOTH 境　and 境界　are often used in the figurative sense - like "This film pushes the envelope of good taste" or "His art blurs the boundary between painting and sculpture".

    Also used in science.
    境 (border) + 界 (the world) = 境界 (boundary)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
境 	border 	EARTH 	土
鏡 	mirror 	METAL 	金

The border is a line on EARTH but the mirror is made of METAL.

Number: 528
競 contest
Star-16Star-16Star-16
20 strokes
立 (stand up) + 兄 (older brother)

ONYOMI: KYOU

KYOU (今日= today), My two older brothers stand up to have a contest with each other.

KUNYOMI:

きそ＊う
    competing to get the best grade, the most sales. 90% overlapping with 競争; same useage and everything. fugeddaboutit.
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

競争 する ( きょうそう する)
    unless youre talking about a literal foot-race, 競争 does not mean a game. It refers to competing within a framework (usually business or academic). The best score on the test, the salesman who sold the most this month.
    競 (contest) + 争 (battle) = 競争 (competition)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
競走 ( きょうそう )
    the more literal word for race: racing cars, sprinting, marathons, etc.
    競 (contest) + 走 (run) = 競走 (race)
    Star-16
競馬 ( けいば )
    horse racing (FP)
    競 (contest) + 馬 (horse) = 競馬 (horse racing)

Number: 530
Legsanimal animal legs
(bottom radical)

DESCRIPTION: OK, you just learned human legs:
. Well heres a new one:
ー animal legs.
Really sorry to do this to you. Youre thinking, "Human legs, animal legs? Who give a shit??? "
But there is a reason -- if you dont make the distinction, you will never be able to distinguish between two of the most common kanji: look (見)and money( 貝).
HOW TO TELL THEM APART:
Human legs are curvy because humans dance. Animal legs are straight because shut up is why.
USED IN:

    貝
    兵
    酸
    四
    養
    典
    黄
    共
    其
    興
    演

Number: 539
質 quality
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
15 strokes
COCK
斤 (axe) + 斤 (axe) + 貝 (shellfish or money)

ONYOMI: SHITSU

These TWO AXES are the best-quality SHIT money can buy.

Look at the quality of this fucking bamboo dude!!

DESCRIPTION: COCK: in almost all the jukugo 質 means quality, BUT the one jukugo that is used 90% of the time, 質 means question!!!

KUNYOMI:

しつ ( が )
    quality, as in しつがいい、or しつ が わるい (the quality is good or bad).
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

質問 する ( しつもん する)
    a question - usually used in a structured setting: interview, trial, test.　

    BOOBOO: in casual conversation, people will say 尋ねる　or 聞く instead of 質問.
    質 (quality) + 問 (question, problem) = 質問 (question)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
品質 の ( ひんしつ の)
    quality of merchandise　(品質のいい or 品質の悪い）
    品 (products) + 質 (quality) = 品質 (quality)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
性質 ( せいしつ )
    natural quality. In contrast to 性格（せいかく）, 性質 applies to rocks and things as well as people and animals. Also it refers to the inner nature of people, rather than their social selves. So if you wanted to say that someone was very outgoing and loved sports and bars, you wouldnt use 性質. But if you wanted to say that someone was very stoic or honest, you would.
    性 (sex or essential nature) + 質 (quality) = 性質 (essential nature)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
皆 	everyone 	WHITE 	白
昆 	insect 	SUN 	陽
質 	quality 	BAMBOO 	竹

Everyones heels trample on WHITE people,

but the SUN shines on insects that crawl on the high QUALITY bamboo.

Number: 547
測 scientific measurment
Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
DUPE
水 (waterleft) + 則 (rule) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: SOKU

We measured the bacteria percolating in his SOCKS.

My rule is to measure your blood and water.

KUNYOMI:

は＊かる
    to measure, but (unlike the other two はかる　kanji) THIS はかる　 usually used in a medical or scientific context. (blood pressure, air pressure).

    Also used for area, distance, sound decibels, angle, capacity.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

推測 する ( すいそく する)
    speculate. Kind of formal: "Its too early to speculate about the economy." "Scientists speculate that..." (NP)
    推 (infer) + 測 (scientific measurment) = 推測 (speculate.)
    Star-16
予測 する ( よそく する)
    predict,forecast
    予 (beforehand) + 測 (scientific measurment) = 予測 (predict)
    Star-16

we measure WATER in cups.

負け犬 ( まけいぬ )
    Since it literally means losing dog, youd think that was a transliteration of the English underdog, But no, it simply means loser or schlemiel. Japan doesnt really have much respect for plucky underdogs who dare to try and rise above their status.
    負 (lose) + 犬 (dog) = 負け犬 (loser)
    Star-16Star-16
負担 ( ふたん )
    a responsibility, usually financial, which is declared by a system. "If a guest falls off the hotel roof, its the hotels responsibility." "The parent is responsible for paying for the childs lunch at boarding school."
    負 (lose) + 担 (carry on your back) = 負担 (financial responsibility)
    - zero stars! -

角 	horn or corner 	UTILIZE 	用

You should of cut corners to make more money, and then use that money to bribe politicians to enact tort reform so the victims of your cut corners or  unsafe cars or botched surgery cant sue you.

Number: 572
完 complete
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
7 strokes
BETA
Crown (crown) + 元 (original)

ONYOMI: KAN

She KAN make a complete replica of the crown if you show her the original.

DESCRIPTION: This motherfucker is used in more synonyms than anyone! Ill do my best to clarify the differences between the synonyms below.
JUKUGO:

完璧 な ( かんぺき な)
    perfect, as in the perfect crime or perfectly safe. Also, perfect as in, My new project is perfectly complete, now the finishing touches are over.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
完成 ( かんせい )
    completion (noun) - usually said of a painting, construction of a building, or other physically creative project.
    完 (complete) + 成 (become) = 完成 (completion)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
完全 な ( かんぜん な)
    complete or total. "Dont stand up until the bus comes to a complete stop." Perfect victory: 100 to nothing. Not used about people, except for this idiom: 完全な人いない (nobodys perfect) 。 Also used when creating things. To perfect a new invention or complete a new artwork.
    完 (complete) + 全 (all) = 完全 (complete)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
完了 する ( かんりょう する)
    to finish work on a project - an annual report, a re-formatting of the database, etc. (NP)
    完 (complete) + 了 (total) = 完了 (finish)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:

Number: 585
材 raw materials
Star-16Star-16

BETA
木 (tree) + オ (Oprah)

JUKUGO:

材料 ( ざいりょう )
    usually seen on the "ingredients" label on food packaging. But also used about source material for a report: field notes, raw data. The implication is that, unlike 素材, the source material is not totally raw, its partially assembled --for instance, if you get silk, thats 素材, but when the silk is woven into a fabric, that is 材料, and then the fabric is an ingredient of a handbag.
    材 (raw materials) + 料 (ingredients or fees) = 材料 (ingredients)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
素材 ( そざい )
    raw material - both literally and figuratively (as in, the raw data that you base your essay or report or novel on) ("Im working on materal for my novel!")
    素 (element) + 材 (raw materials) = 素材 (raw material)
    Star-16Star-16
木材 ( もくざい )
    raw lumber
    木 (tree) + 材 (raw materials) = 木材 (raw lumber)

    rule or regulation

    Star-16Star-16Star-16
規律 ( きりつ )
    literally, "rule," but closer to the English word for "discipline."Rules typically say "dont do this or that," but 規律 give long lists of things you HAVE TO do, in the order you have to do them. Like if youre at military school, you have to get up at 5:30, have your bed made by 5:35, shine your shoes by 5:40, and report to the mess hall.
    規 (criteria) + 律 (regulation) = 規律 (rules or discipline)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    規 (criteria) + 準 (prepare or criteria) = 規準 (a criterion)

Number: 594
巣 habitat
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
11 strokes
Hay (t.c.f.b.b.y.e.s.i.y.l.) + 果 (fruit　 or  result)

ONYOMI: SOU

The baby birds build a habitat in the top of the tree SO they can feed on the fruit.

KUNYOMI:

す
    BOOBOO: this is usually translated as nest, but anywhere an animal lives is a SU. A spiders web, a badgers burrow, are all 巣.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

精巣 ( せいそう )
    ：A very archaic word for ｔｅｓｔｉｃｌｅｓ！　Although youll never use this, the roots are so awesome, I had to include it the balls are apparently the spiritual habitat of men. (FR, OBSOLETE)
    精 (spirit) + 巣 (habitat) = 精巣 (balls)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
早 	early 	SUN 	陽
巣 	habitat 	TREE 	木
単 	merely 	BABY BIRDS 	Hay

The SUN rises early.

The habitat is in a TREE.

Merely has NO TREE because it is MERELY some baby birds.

Number: 596
単 merely
Star-16Star-16Star-16
9 strokes
Hay (t.c.f.b.b.y.e.s.i.y.l.) + 田 (rice field) + 十 (ten)

ONYOMI: TAN

as in I was hit with a flame thrower (long story) but it MERELY gave me a TAN. 

Even though I have ten rice fields, all that is growing is merely three lousy baby firds, I mean birds.

KUNYOMI:

たん*に
    merely
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

単語 ( たんご )
    a SIMPLE Japanese word (note the 単 kanji) : 犬 is a tango, as is a hiragana word like イヤ. But compound words or long-ass words are not tango.
    単 (merely) + 語 (language) = 単語 (simple word)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
簡単 な ( かんたん な)
    simple or easy, but in a good way
    簡 (simplicity) + 単 (merely) = 簡単 (simple)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
単位 ( たんい )
    denomination or unit (college credit, but also centimeter or pound)
    単 (merely) + 位 (rank) = 単位 (unit)
    Star-16
単純 な ( たんじゅん な)
    the simple kind of X as opposed to the complicated kind (not rude). Also, simple-minded, mouth-breathing person (pretty rude).
    単 (merely) + 純 (epitome) = 単純 (simple version)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
早 	early 	SUN 	陽
巣 	habitat 	TREE 	木
単 	merely 	BABY BIRDS 	Hay

The SUN rises early.

The habitat is in a TREE.

Merely has NO TREE because it is MERELY some baby birds.

    弾
    戦

Number: 608
久 been a long time
Star-16Star-16Star-16
3 strokes
PN, SOLO
ク (katakana ku) + 人 (person)

ONYOMI: KYUU

Its been a long time since I kissed the KUchie of a CUTE person.
JUKUGO:

永久 に ( えいきゅう に)
    forever - the science word. (BOOBOO : the poetic word is eien.(永遠))
    永 (forever) + 久 (been a long time) = 永久 (forever )
    Star-16Star-16
耐久性 ( たいきゅうせい )
    durability (NP)
    耐 (withstand) + 久 (been a long time) + 性 (sex or essential nature) = 耐久性 (durability)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
及 	reach or amount to 	right side BUMPY 	
各 	each 	CROSSed lines 	
久 	been a long time 	bottom GOES APART 	

grasp - the right line has what looks like BUMPS on it - those bumps are the WHITE KNUCKLES of the grasping hand.

久s diagonal lines do NOT cross - they go APART. 　各s diagonal lines DO cross. So you can say:

Each time we met,you double-CROSSed me, so its been a long time since weve been apart.


Number: 609
各 each
Star-16Star-16Star-16
6 strokes
STRONG, PRE, BETA, MR
口 (mouth or small box radical) + ??? (???)
MUTANTS:

Each
    eachbottom

ONYOMI: KAKU

Allright! Lets call that weird thing on top your nose. Youll notice that it looks a LOT like the kanji for been a long time : 久. But 久s diagonal lines do NOT cross. 　各s diagonal lines DO cross.

So! Now we are ready to do our mnemonic, which will help us remember the difference between the two kanji:

Each COCK in your mouth crosses your nose.

DESCRIPTION: STRONG for both かく　and らく!
JUKUGO:

各駅停車 ( かくえきていしゃ )
    sure this is a scary and long word, but if you live here, youll use it everyday： It means "local train" (literally, "stopping at each station train")
    各 (each) + 駅 (train station) + 停 (bring to a halt) + 車 (car) = 各駅停車 (local train)
    Star-16Star-16
各々 のxxx ( おのおの のxxx)
    each thing in its own way. 各々考え方が違います。 (everyone thinks in their own way or  everyone has their own opinion). (1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16
各 ｘｘｘ ( かく ｘｘｘ)
    PREFIX- you can put 各　in front of a noun to make it mean "each one, respectively"：each place, each thing, person.　 (PRE)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
及 	reach or amount to 	right side BUMPY 	
各 	each 	CROSSed lines 	
久 	been a long time 	bottom GOES APART 	

grasp - the right line has what looks like BUMPS on it - those bumps are the WHITE KNUCKLES of the grasping hand.

久s diagonal lines do NOT cross - they go APART. 　各s diagonal lines DO cross. So you can say:

Each time we met,you double-CROSSed me, so its been a long time since weve been apart.

Number: 612
落 fall,drop
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
PN, DUPE
Flower (flowertop) + 水 (waterleft) + 各 (each) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: RAKU

DESCRIPTION: Christ! Two out of three radicals are mutants. The mutant invasion has begun!!!

KUNYOMI:

( を ) お＊とす
    I drop something.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
( が ) お＊ちる
    something falls (fall off your chair, a plate falls and breaks)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

堕落 してる ( だらく してる)
    corrupt in ones personal life - not usually political corruption. Drugs, lies, trife behavior.
    堕 (corrupt) + 落 (fall,drop) = 堕落 (corrupt)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
落ち着く ( おちつく )
    to keep your cool. Often said as a command： おちつけ!!
    落 (fall,drop) + 着 (wear or arrive) = 落ち着く (keep your cool.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
部落民 ( ぶらくみん )
    (literally,the fallen group.) this is - along with Ainu, Korean ex-slaves, the Eta-hin,and the handicapped, one of the main groups discriminated against in Japan. I wont go into the whole story here, but most Japanese will say, Dont say ぶらくみん, its 差別 (さべつ＝ discriminatory) What they neglect to tell you is, there is no polite word! Effectively denying these people a voice in the guise of being polite to them. This is a very. Very. Japanese way of fucking with people. (CCW, ABU, FR)
    部 (section) + 落 (fall,drop) + 民 (folk) = 部落民 (burakumin)
    Star-16Star-16
落第 する ( らくだい する)
    fail an exam,or get held back a grade.
    落 (fall,drop) + 第 (rank or number in series) = 落第 (fail a test)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
落 	fall,drop 	FLOWERS 	花
夜 	late night 	BERET 	Lid

FLOWERS fall on me when I wear my BERET at night .

ONYOMI: KAKU

You should judge a mans character by the size of his COCK.

Each species of tree has a different character - some are tall, some are dignified, some are gnarly and some are just on fire.

DESCRIPTION: A classic JERK kanji; it means personality, shape, AND pass test!
JUKUGO:

格好 ( かっこう )
    literally, look or shape, as in Hes dressed as a woman : おんなの格好してる。

    But　usually it means coolness: かっこいい (cool) or かっこうわるい (not).(when used in the figurative, cool sense, it is usually KANA) (1 or 2 KANA)
    格 (character, aspect) + 好 (like) = 格好 (looks)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
性格 ( せいかく )
    personality
    性 (sex or essential nature) + 格 (character, aspect) = 性格 (personality)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
合格 する ( ごうかく する)
    pass a test.(opposite： ふごうかく)
    合 (to suit) + 格 (character, aspect) = 合格 (pass test)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
絡 	get entangled 	STRING 	糸
格 	character, aspect 	TREE 	木
略 	abbreviation 	RICEFIELD 	田

You get entangled in STRING,
The Ents are TREEs, who were characters in Lord of the Rings.
And. . . .um . . .and you abbreviate a RICEFIELD when you harvest the rice.

    Star-16

    article 9 of the constitution, which states that Japan cant have an army. Right? WRONG. Japan CAN have an army - they just arent allowed to invade, an inconvinient fact that both pacifists AND right-wingers seem to forget.

A CHILD grows every season,

but a WOMAN is a member of the MILF club.

EACH clause in the contract forbids flexible HALBERDS.

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
及 	reach or amount to 	right side BUMPY 	
各 	each 	CROSSed lines 	
久 	been a long time 	bottom GOES APART 	

grasp - the right line has what looks like BUMPS on it - those bumps are the WHITE KNUCKLES of the grasping hand.

久s diagonal lines do NOT cross - they go APART. 　各s diagonal lines DO cross. So you can say:

Each time we met,you double-CROSSed me, so its been a long time since weve been apart.
USED IN:

    吸
    扱
    級

Number: 628
扱 treatment
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
6 strokes
SOLO
Hand (handleft) + 及 (reach or amount to)

ONYOMI:

You reach your hand out to someone: whether you shake their hand or punch them is your treatment of them.

KUNYOMI:

あつか*い
    Treatment - usually applied to people, but originally used for objects, so it s a little rude. Usually used like あつかいがいい or あつかいがわるい. Can mean treatment of others but, confusingly, can ALSO mean easy or hard for ME to DEAL WITH HIM or HER. For example, 彼は扱いが難しい does NOT mean He treats me difficultly, it means Hes difficult to deal with. (noun)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
あつか＊う
    treatment(verb)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

取り扱い ( とりあつかい )
    Treatment - but unlike 扱う, 取り扱う is ONLY used for objects or cases. i.e. The police are handling the racial hate-crime very carefully.
    取 (take) + 扱 (treatment) = 取り扱い (management)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
扱 	treatment 	REACH (grasping hand) 	Grab
抜 	extract 	FRIEND 	友

You REACH out for treatment with your grasping hand,

but only your FRIEND will extract your tumors.

    本 (book or the real) + 当 (hit the target) = 本当 (for realz.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
適当 な ( てきとう な)
    appropriate, as in an appropriate gift. However, 適当　also means irresponsible! Doing something without considering the consequences. 適当な人間だ！ “Hes irresponsible. Hell say anything that pops into his head.” (JERK)
    適 (suitable) + 当 (hit the target) = 適当 (appropriate)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
当然 の ( とうぜん の)
    just, natural, deserved - although its often used like Thats obvious, isnt it?
    当 (hit the target) + 然 (nature) = 当然 (natural, obvious)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
当日 に ( とうじつ に)
    that day . . .
    当 (hit the target) + 日 (sun, day) = 当日 (that day . . .)
    Star-16Star-16

ONYOMI: FU

That is FUCKED up that while youre out working , your housewife is fucking a pig-snouted sword-swallower.

DESCRIPTION: Is this a Fucked Radical? Theres nothing inherently bad about the right-hand radicals "snout + swordswallower" (remember, theyre just names I made up) - but the only other two kanji that have that particular combo are "go home" and "clean house." So you be the judge. . .

Number: 648
控 abstain
Star-16
11 strokes
Hand (handleft) + 空 (air)

ONYOMI: KOU

Abstain from COCAINE! When your hand reaches out for it, it just grabs empty air instead. Because I snatched your little mirror. Zoinks!

KUNYOMI:

ひか*える
    Sometimes means to wait, but often means, to repress ones true feelings or refrain from actions you really secretly want to do. 

    Pretty much the same as 抑える、 but there are two important distinctions: 抑える is something you do because society forces you to, but 控える is something you do because YOU want to. Also 控える is usually used about repressing or refraining from doing ACTIONS, while 抑える usually referrs to only repressing feelings.
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

控え室 ( ひかえしつ )
    waiting room
    控 (abstain) + 室 (room) = 控え室 (waiting room)
    Star-16Star-16

    儀 (politeness) + 式 (ritual) = 儀式 (ceremony)

Timberrrr! is like Generation but with an EXTRA LINE -which you can think of as a SPEAR striking down a whole generation.

"Stick to" is the only kanji where the dot is on the inside, so you could think of it as a dot of GLUE making the left and right right radicals stick to each other.

我 we

    us (kind of formal, an older guy word) (gives the impression that youre making a speech) (F)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
われ＊われ
    like われ but more so! (F)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

我慢 する ( がまん する)
    to endure, to bear something. Often translated as patience, but that is not quite right. You have patience if you can do data entry on a fucking kanji dictionary for 5 hours straight, but you gaman with your overtime or while taking final exams with a burst appendix.

    Masochists tend to gaman when theyre fed worms while tied up.

    Sometimes the concept of gaman DOES overlap with the English idea of patience, though: Little kids have to gaman if they find out that Disneyland is still 4 hours away.

    One possible way to make GAMAN fit with the theme of neglect is to remember that the ga part means self. So GAMAN means neglect yourself, or, more poetically, Stop feeling the pain of your body and mind, and concentrate on the task at hand. (CCW, 1 or 2 KANA)
    我 (we) + 慢 (neglect or  egotistic) = 我慢 (persevere)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
怪我 ( けが )
    visible evidence of damage: scars, cuts, bruises. Both new and old scars. (KANA, FP)
    怪 (suspicious) + 我 (we) = 怪我 (scar)
    Star-16

USED IN:

    義

    Star-16Star-16
巨乳 ( きょにゅう )
    tig ole biddies (ABU)
    巨 (giant super huge) + 乳 (milk) = 巨乳 (tig ole biddies)
    Star-16
巨根 ( きょこん )
    Think you can figure this one out? (ABU)
    巨 (giant super huge) + 根 (root) = 巨根 (thats right: monster cock.)
    Star-16

USED IN:

    拒
    距
    臣



Number: 686
拒 repel
Star-16Star-16
8 strokes
Hand (handleft) + 巨 (giant super huge) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: KYO

Keep Your Odors to yourself - I repel them!

David used his hands to repel the giant.

KUNYOMI:

こば*む
    absolute refusal - it can be physical as well as verbal. For example, if someone refuses to shake your hand, thats 拒む。
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

拒否 する ( きょひ する)
    absolute refusal- unlike 拒む (こばむ）,　拒否 is always verbal - an exit line. Like if you tell a guy no thanks 10 times and he wont go away, you use 拒否. As in, 私がきょひした。’

    Oh no you diint! (ABU)
    拒 (repel) + 否 (no) = 拒否 (refuse!!!!)
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

距離 ( きょり )
    physical distance between two things: towns on a map, for instance, or the distance between an archer and a target - a much bigger distance than the related word 間隔.

You oversee the PLATE (youre a waiter)

The EARTH is very solid.

    Star-16Star-16
御覧 ( ごらん )
    a formal way of asking your superior to view something. either ごらん ください or ごらん に なる. (F)
    御 (the honorific "o") + 覧 (view) = 御覧 (please look sir)
    Star-16Star-16
博覧会 ( はくらんかい )
    a GIANT exposition. Not like, "Cezannes greatest fuckin paintings all up in here festival" but huger - like a Worlds Fair.

    To break it down:

    博覧会 (biggest　kind of expo )

    　展示会（てんじかい＝trade show)

    展覧会 （てんらんかい＝art exhibition)
    博 (museum　 or extensive) + 覧 (view) + 会 (big meeting) = 博覧会 (exposition)
    Star-16

Number: 697

ABU

DESCRIPTION: Along with 7、 4 is one of the numbers where the KUN and ON are used pretty randomly. Like, more than usual. When counting months, usually one uses the kuns, but with 4 and 7 you use the ONs.

    4 oclock

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
四時間 ( よじかん )
    4 hours time. As in, this bus ride takes 4 hours.
    四­時 (4 oclock) + 間 (a period of time) = 四時間 (4 hours time)

欠 lack
Star-16Star-16Star-16
4 strokes
人 (person) + Rifle (rifle)

I lack KETCHUP. please pass it over here.

You could say that the person LACKS a functioning rifle. And then you could giggle about that if you were, you know, immatoor.

KUNYOMI:

( に ) か＊ける
    to lack an abstract thing (experience or confidence or creativity or trust) （BOOBOO: if you want to say you dont have enough of a physical thing (for instance, money!) youd say 足りない (たりない）instead.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

欠点 がある or 　がない ( けってん がある or 　がない)
    shortcoming. Opposite of 長所（ちょうしょ）. Can be used about people (he drinks too much, she always lies) or machines (this PC is very slow and prone to crashing).
    欠 (lack) + 点 (point) = 欠点 (shortcoming)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
欠陥 のある ( けっかん のある)
    defective, defect
    欠 (lack) + 陥 (entrapped) = 欠陥 (defective)
    Star-16Star-16
欠席 する ( けっせき する)
    A kind of formal word for failure to attend, absence. (F)
    欠 (lack) + 席 (seat) = 欠席 (absent)
    Star-16

Number: 705
Taskmaster director
PK
(right radical)

DESCRIPTION:Helsig calls this incredibly common radical the TASKMASTER, because it usually shows up in kanji about learning or organized procedures.

That makes sense, but I prefer to call him the DIRECTOR, as you can easily picture his imperious figure sitting on this cliche Hollywood directors chair with the crossed legs:
. . .the tallness of the chair allows him to oversee his underlings every move, and hector them appropriately.

LOOKALIKES：

Lack (欠)is spreading its legs because it LACKS good manners,but the directors chair, by definition, has crossed legs.

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
大失敗 ( だいしっぱい )
    a total disaster.
    大 (big) + 失­敗 (any failure! Flunking a test, your plan fails, no one comes to your party, your business goes bankrupt, your moms chest waxing goes wrong and her pec-fro winds up as Beyonces wig.) = 大失敗 (total disaster)
    Star-16Star-16



Number: 710
故 breakdown, accident
Star-16Star-16Star-16

BETA
古 (old) + Taskmaster (director)

The director is so old, he keeps having accidents on set.

    reason
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

事故 ( じこ )
    accident - not like you spilled your Coke, but like a traffic accident or a dude getting smeared by a meteorite.
    事 (action or  incident) + 故 (breakdown, accident) = 事故 (accident)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
何故 ( なぜ )
    a slightly more emphatic version of "Why?" (1 or 2 KANA)
    何 (what?!?) + 故 (breakdown, accident) = 何故 (why)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

繁殖 ( はんしょく )
    breeding. Unlike the related term 生殖 （せいしょく）、繁殖 refers to the entire process of finding a mate, not just the physical act of insemination: Breeding grounds. Mating season. Farmers breeding livestock.

Number: 722
己 myself
Star-16Star-16
3 strokes
PK, STRONG

ONYOMI: KO

The sound of the word KO makes you think of kodomo(子), and 己 looks like a snake, so you could say:

I myself, am a baby snake.

DESCRIPTION:Although the onyomi for this is KO, it is STRONG FOR KI, - which is to say, most of the kanji using this as a radical have the onyomi of KI for some reason!

おのれ
    myself- a very LITERARY way of saying 私 (F)

    Star-16Star-16
自己 ( じこ )
    Ones own (as in, self-control, self-hate, self-help books, ones own discretion)
    自 (my own) + 己 (myself) = 自己 (ones own)

    Star-16Star-16
改造 ( かいぞう )
    remodeling, renewal, or reorganization　of a physical thing ; re-modeling a house, tricking out a car, re-organizing the leadership of an organization.
    改 (renew or improve) + 造 (produce) = 改造 (remodeling, renewal)

Star-16Star-16
14 strokes
BETA
Cliff (cliff) + 林 (grove) + 止 (stop)

ONYOMI: REKI

RAY KEEPS a chronicle of the time he stopped under a cliff and found a grove of hella bud growing there.

DESCRIPTION: This kind of means permanent record, as in, Young man, this will go on your. . .

Its used a lot in words relating to school or business experience, but who cares. Basically you only need the following ２ words：
JUKUGO:

歴史 ( れきし )
    history
    歴 (chronicle) + 史 (history) = 歴史 (history)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
履歴書 ( りれきしょ )
    ones work resume.
    履 (put on pants or shoes) + 歴 (chronicle) + 書 (write) = 履歴書 (ones work resume.)
    Star-16Star-16

    this is the main word youll use with this kanji: prepare (packing for a vacation, getting the restaurant ready to open for the day, and putting on makeup are all junbi).
    準 (prepare or criteria) + �� (furnish) = 準 (get ready)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
警備 する ( けいび する)
    the type of guard who protects innocent people: the security guy at the bank, the Secret Service.
    警 (the fuzz) + 備 (furnish) = 警備 (guard)
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 740
産 childbirth, production of things

DUPE, FR

SANTA Claus stands on top of the cliff and produces toys, giving them life, and then they roll downhill into your chimney.

DESCRIPTION: a bit of a FR (women are child factories? According to Japanese politicians, yes.)

KUNYOMI:

う*む
    to give birth (human or animal) .This is more of a medical or agricultural word. Normally we use the OTHER うむ　（生む） for everyday childbirth. (NP)

    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    heavy industry, like the steel or construction industry.
    産 (childbirth, production of things) + 業 (business) = 産業 (heavy industry)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    production
    生 (life or birth) + 産 (childbirth, production of things) = 生産 (production)

Number: 741

JERK, ILL PAIR

Ill go back to my origins AGAIN: I originated on a tiny white cliff. (FYI, Im a cormorant, coming home to the ol guano colony to mate)

DESCRIPTION: JERK - by itself it means high plain, but used with another kanji it means original

KUNYOMI:

はら
    a high plain. (not useful, unless you are a High Plains Drifter, and concoct a Black and Tan in your brandy Snifter)

JUKUGO:

    origin or cause of something
    原 (original or  high plain) + 因 (origin) = 原因 (cause)

    the A-bomb　(a contraction of 原子爆弾 (げんしばくだん)) (NEO)
    原 (original or  high plain) + 爆 (explode) = 原爆 (A-bomb　)
    Star-16
原住民 ( げんじゅうみん )
    a person or animal native to the area. Indigenous.
    原 (original or  high plain) + 住­民 (residents) = 原住民 (native)
    - zero stars! -

Number: 743
反 anti
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
4 strokes
STRONG, BETA
Cliff (cliff) + 又 (again or crotch radical)

ONYOMI: HAN

HAN Solo threw your Moms crotch off a cliff because hes anti-herpes.
JUKUGO:

反対 する ( はんたい する)
    to be against something
    反 (anti) + 対 (against) = 反対 (against it!!!!!!!!!!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
反則 ( はんそく )
    foul! To break a rule!
    反 (anti) + 則 (rule) = 反則 (foul! To break a rule!)
    Star-16Star-16
反抗 する ( はんう する)
    to be rebellious, defiant. To start a revolt. Unlike the related words 抵抗　（ていこう）　and 対抗　（たいこう）、　反抗 has the nuance of rebel for the fuck of it, like a teenager would.
    反 (anti) + 抗 (oppose) = 反抗 (rebel)
    Star-16Star-16
反応 ( はんのう )
    a reaction - despite the 反 kanji, 反応 is not neccesairly a bad reaction. As a noun, its value-free. (careful! This is pronounced NOU, not OU) (FP)
    反 (anti) + 応 (react) = 反応 (a reaction )
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
反 	anti 	CLIFF 	Cliff
友 	friend 	NARUTO 	Naruto

Jason Newsted was seen as the Anti - CLIFF by old-school Metallica fans.
NARUTO is your friend if youre an anime nerd.

Alternate mnemonic: only FRIEND has a "head" poking up above the horizontal line, and friends have heads.

Number: 745
坂 slope
Star-16Star-16Star-16
7 strokes

HAN solo, accustomed to the zero-gravity of space, is against climbing the steep slopes of the earth!

さか
    a slope of a hill (BOOBOO: not the hill itself. Hills are the similar-sounding おか！）
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

下り坂 ( くだりざか )
    A noun meaning, "the act of going downhill." Unhelpfully, this is not used as a verb. What the hell, man?
    下 (below) + 坂 (slope) = 下り坂 (go downhill )
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

The board is made of WOOD
The PERSON is provisionally good (before xmas).

The EARTH has slopes called hills.

Number: 749
Open scissors open scissors
PK
(right or top radical)

DESCRIPTION:

LOOKALIKE- Dont get the open scissors confused with the nail radical (丁)which has a mutant version that looks like this:
You can tell them apart because the NAIL has an OVERHANG on the right: the head of the nail!

OK - here is a warning. . . starting now, there are going to be hella lookalikes, even more than usual. As usual,Ive tried to group them side-by-side so you can compare them easily and see the differences. Once you memorize the differences then you wont be so confused by them. After about 200 kanji, it calms down a little. So dont panic. . .
USED IN:

    司
    幻
    気
    決
    快
    成
    寸

Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
6 strokes
Cliff (cliff) + Spearthree (spear) + Open scissors (open scissors)

ONYOMI: SEI

If you SAY youll get good at kanji, eventually you will become good.

The scissors fell off the cliff and became dangerous spears, piercing the brains of innocent people below. (see also: pennies dropped off Empire State Building become bullets)

KUNYOMI:

( に ) な＊る
    to become (1 or 2 KANA)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

完成 ( かんせい )
    completion (noun) - usually said of a painting, construction of a building, or other physically creative project.
    完 (complete) + 成 (become) = 完成 (completion)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
成功 する ( せいこう する)
    success
    成 (become) + 功 (success) = 成功 (success)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
成程 ( なるほど )
    "ohhhh, now I see!" (very similar to a hearty 分かった！！　（わかった）, but it also has the nuance of, understanding AND agreeing whole-heartedly) (KANA, KUNKUN)
    成 (become) + 程 (extent) = 成程 (oh, I see!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 752
越 go beyond
Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
DUPE, ILL PAIR
走 (run) + 成 (become)

ONYOMI:

The Nazis ran BEYOND the limits of good taste and became extinct.

DESCRIPTION: Unlike the OTHER こす　（超す） , which means go OVER (a number or limit), THIS 越す means go BEYOND - physically.

KUNYOMI:

( を ) こ＊す
    I go beyond (a physical thing) - I pass or crosss something (a lake, a city, etc)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    something crosses something else
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

    move to a new house or apartment

    overtake
    追 (follow) + 越 (go beyond) = 追い越す (overtake)

Number: 755
歳 years old
Star-16Star-16Star-16
13 strokes
COUNTER
止 (stop) + 成 (become) + 小 (small size)

ONYOMI: SAI

He SIGHed as he turned another year old. Closer to the grave, my friend, closer to the grave!

When you turn 10 years old you stop being small, and you become a tween!
JUKUGO:

xxx 歳 (xxx さい )
    counter for "years old" that a person is. (COUNTER)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
万歳 ( ばんざい! )
    Fuckin banzai, man!!!! (literally 10,000 years, meaning, May the Emperor live 10,000 years! is what you shout as you charge into battle) (1 or 2 KANA)
    万 (10000) + 歳 (years old) = 万歳 (banzai!)
    Star-16Star-16
二十歳 ( はたち )
    twenty years old - traditionally the age at which Japanese turn into adults and get presents, kimono, etc. So, naturally it has its own special pronunciation that doesnt make any sense, since it SHOULD be called にじゅうさい。 Whatever. Tradition. (FP, CCW)
    二 (two) + 十 (ten) + 歳 (years old) = 二十歳 (twenty years old)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
厳 	strict 	NEEDLE 	針

威 	terrible majesty 	WOMAN 	女

The strict nurse injects you with a NEEDLE,

but the drug STOPS you from aging.

Both FIRE AND WATER can annihilate a city,

but that WOMAN has a terrible majesty even more scary!


Number: 756
滅 annihilate
Star-16Star-16
13 strokes

ONYOMI: METSU

A flood of water and a hail of fire, together they become a wave of annihilation!

KUNYOMI:

( が ) ほろ＊びる
    to get fucked up.
    - zero stars! -
( を ) ほろ＊ぼす
    to annhilate - usually used about an enemy in wartime, or destroy the earth, or wipe Al Queda out. Not used about a single person usually.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

滅亡 ( めつぼう )
    the downfall of a civilization or the dying-out of a certain ethnic group. But it doesnt have downfalls moral judgement.
    滅 (annihilate) + 亡 (dying) = 滅亡 (downfall)
    Star-16Star-16
撲滅 する ( ぼくめつ する)
    eradicate (a pest or disease) The new task force will eradicate drugs once and for all!
    撲 (eradicate) + 滅 (annihilate) = 撲滅 (eradicate)
    - zero stars! -
絶滅 する ( ぜつめつ する)
    go extinct
    絶 (extinct) + 滅 (annihilate) = 絶滅 (go extinct)

Number: 757
威 terrible majesty
Star-16
9 strokes
BETA, CCW
成 (become) + 女 (woman)

ONYOMI: I

The dude became a woman, and as she vogued majestically, and I was scared!

DESCRIPTION:This is one of the most "no-English-equivalent-y" words in the whole Japanese language. Why is majestic stuff scary? Who is scared of Prince? Hes like five feet tall. I guess you have to think like a medieval peasant to really get the meaning.
JUKUGO:

威厳 のある ( いげん のある)
    majestic , slow and dignified but scary - like a bunch of gangsters slowly walking down the street while the Peter Gunn theme plays. Or a parade float of your moms neck-beard.
    威 (terrible majesty) + 厳 (strict) = 威厳 (majestic or scary)
    Star-16Star-16
権威 ( けんい )
    an authority one has based on power alone (parents, cops, etc.) rather than on rights (authority based on rights is　権利（けんり））
    権 (rights) + 威 (terrible majesty) = 権威 (authority)
    Star-16Star-16
威張ってる ( いばってる )
    arrogant (1 or 2 KANA)
    威 (terrible majesty) + 張 (stretch) = 威張ってる (arrogant)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
厳 	strict 	NEEDLE 	針
歳 	years old 	STOP 	止
滅 	annihilate 	FIRE AND WATER 	水

The strict nurse injects you with a NEEDLE,

but the drug STOPS you from aging.

but that WOMAN has a terrible majesty even more scary!

    basically, mood, but there are over 3,000 expressions that use it. KI can be put in, become exhausted ,become lost, change, be pulled, be big, small, changing. KI gets followed, met, used, lightened, lengthened, shortened, rotated, cut. KI can be strong, weak, floating, heavy. . .. but you never say, "hows your ki doing ?" or "Ive got great ki today!" - You have to use it as part of an expression. (CCW)

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
気違い ( きちがい )
    (literally, different feeling) crazy - this is one of the biggest cusses in the whole language-a garunteed fight-starter. This is instructive in several ways.

    1) Japanese is such a polite language that different feeling is one of the worst insults.

    2) it takes a certain kind of culture to think that having a different feeling is such a bad thing in the first place!

    3) Historically it is a discriminatory term against people who suffer from mental illness. (ABU)
    気 (mood) + 違 (different and therefore wrong) = 気違い (fuckin crazy)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
気付いた ( きづいた )
    to belatedly realize something - doh! (also pronounced 気がついた）
    気 (mood) + 付 (stick to) = 気付いた (realize something)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    Just for fun, do you wanna (blah blah blah)?"
    気 (mood) + 晴 (weather get good now) = 気晴らし (Just for fun)

Number: 776
Far far away

USED IN:

Number: 777
遠 far
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
13 strokes
Moving (motion) + 土 (earth) + Far (far away) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: EN

Please ENjoy the trip as you move to a far away place on earth.

KUNYOMI:

とお*い
    far away
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

遠慮 する ( えんりょ する)
    CULTURAL CODE WORD in full effect. Meaning, its such a uniquely Japanese concept there is no ready English equivalent.

    遠慮 means to be diplomatically, politely refuse, to regretfully decline.

    For example, "You want the last donut?" "Hell yes!" is not 遠慮.

    But, "No way I dont want it, it smells!" is also not 遠慮 .

    "Thanks but Im full now." is the 遠慮 answer, since it means, "We both know I want it, but since I abstained from it, you owe me one, now! The favor-ball is back in my court!"

    Used most commonly in two situations：

    1) 遠慮せず： meaning, Act casual. Eat the last pie. Dont wait for all the food to be served. Sit wherever. Make yourself at home.

    2) its often seen on signs telling you not to do something: XXX遠慮してくさい。 (Please refrain from doing XXX) (CCW, F)
    遠 (far) + 慮 (consideration) = 遠慮 (regretfully decline or enjoin from)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
永遠 に ( えいえん に)
    the poetic forever： Ill hate you forever! We shall rule the world forever!
    永 (forever) + 遠 (far) = 永遠 (poetic forever)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    Tokyo -to. Tokyo is the capital of Japan, so　it has "-to" on the end of it. Most cities have a 市（し） instead. And most prefectures have a 県 (けん） instead. If you think thats confusing, look at Washington DC - its not a state, but its not a city. Its a "district." Huh?
    東­京 (Tokyo) + 都 (major city) = 東京都 (capital city)

Number: 828
面 front surface or face
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
9 strokes
COCK
Terrorist (terrorist) + Box (big box) + ??? (???)

ONYOMI: MEN

KUNYOMI:

めん
    2 meanings
    1) ENTIRE surface of a 3-dimensional object, as opposed to 表, which is the front surface of a 2-D object (deeeeyammn!!),
    2) the head or face - usually used in the context of expressions like meet face to face or dare you to say it to my face!. In other words, you wouldnt tell a drunk model, Hey there, nice 面！’
    Star-16Star-16
づら
    Yakuza slang for face: I cant believe youd dare show your face around here!  (ABU)
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

面白*い ( おもしろい )
    interesting, (in a good way) but also can mean funny (as in, laughing at you!) this deliberate ambiguity being a big thing with Japanese Sarcasm. Although in this case, fully half the time people are being serious. (SARC)
    面 (front surface or face) + 白 (white) = 面白*い (interesting)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
面倒臭い ( めんどうくさい )
    annoying, a pain in the ass.
    面­倒 (trouble, petty bullshit) + 臭 (SUFFIX meaning XXX and therefore dumb. 古臭い　（ふるくさい) is one example　（so out of fashion that it is stinking) , also 田舎くさい　（いなくさい） - meaning like stoopid redneck. ) = 面倒臭い (pain in the ass)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
画面 ( がめん )
    screen - both movie screen and computer or tv screen
    画 (a drawing) + 面 (front surface or face) = 画面 (screen)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
地面 ( じめん )
    the ground or floor (applies both inside and outside)
    地 (area) + 面 (front surface or face) = 地面 (ground)
    Star-16Star-16
面目を保つ ( めんぼくをたもつ )
    to save face (opposite: 面目を失う　（めんぼくをうしなう）） (CCW)
    面 (front surface or face) + 目 (eye) + 保 (guarantee or maintain ) = 面目を保つ (save face)
    Star-16
表面 ( ひょうめん )
    the exterior, the surface - unlike 面 (men), 表面 is more technical - usually used by architects or craftspeople. Or, for instance, to describe a "skin" youd put on a polygon 3d character.
    表 (express) + 面 (front surface or face) = 表面 (exterior)
    - zero stars! -

Number: 831
優 kindhearted or excel

YOU are such a kindhearted person to grieve for the loss of my moms cousins great-aunt twice removed, whom youve never even met!

In other words, a kindhearted PERSON often excels at grief.

DESCRIPTION: JERK: by itself, it means nice, but in a JUKUGO, it means EXCEL, or, for some reason, ACTOR.

Also this kanji has the distinction of being a DOUBLE dupe: theres two やさしいs AND two すぐれるs!

KUNYOMI:

やさ＊しい
    warm-hearted. , emphasis on the personality, They make people feel comfortable and understand the feelings of others. Young people can use 優しい人 as kind of a put-down, like "Hes just a nice guy."

( に ) ずぐ＊れる
    to outdo, to be superior.

Number: 846
岸 shore
Star-16Star-16
8 strokes
SIDEKICK
山 (mountain) + Cliff (cliff) + 干 (dry out)

ONYOMI: GAN

GHANDI is standing on shore, listening to some rap.

Theres a telephone pole at the base of the mountain cliff, on the shore of the lake. This pole warns sailors theyre about to crash into the shore.

KUNYOMI:

きし
    shore
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

海岸 ( かいがん )
    the coast OR the beach! Unlike 浜辺 or 浜, 海岸 has a scientific meaning: the coastline, (regardless of if theres sand or not). Youll see 海岸 on maps or geography books. The useage of 海岸 is odd, even for Japanese. Where Americans will just say, "Lets go to the beach!", Japanese might suggest to their pals, "海へ行こう！”（lets go to the ocean!) but ONLY ONCE THEY WERE ALREADY THERE, then they might specifically suggest going to the 海岸 - as opposed to other things to do by the sea. Weird!　
    海 (ocean) + 岸 (shore) = 海岸 (coast or beach)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

The animals cry with their MOUTHS.
The bird has four little LEGS,

Number: 894
様 important person
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
14 strokes
SUF, JERK
木 (tree) + 羊 (sheep) (Same-ON) + 水 (water)

ONYOMI: YOU

Youre a very important person, so here is your complimentary sheep, your jug of water, and your free tree, as well as a 30-minute YODELING telegram which you can not turn off nor refuse.

DESCRIPTION: OK, this is kind of a JERK, now that I think about it. It means important person - and in those cases it uses the KUN reading (さま）. But it also means the situation, and in THOSE cases, it uses the ON reading (よう). What the hell, man?

KUNYOMI:

( xxx ) さま
    SUFFIX which goes after someones name to be polite. (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

皆様 ( みんなさま )
    a more formal way to say "everyone." (F, KUNKUN)
    皆 (everyone) + 様 (important person) = 皆様 (everyone)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
模様 ( もよう )
    a pattern which does not have pictures: fractals , mandala, plaid, zeebra skin. wood. do NOT use about representational patterns like flower-print or kids’ pajamas with horsies on them. 模様 also has a more formal meaning: ‘the details of an incident’ : You might hear a train or airport announcement which says "We will explain the details of the delay" ( 遅れるの模様。 ) (1 or 2 KANA)
    模 (model) + 様 (important person) = 模様 (pattern)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
様子 ( ようす )
    the situation. Usually used in medicine or business: The patients situation is grave. Well wait and see if the market situation improves. 様子を見ましょう！ The other main way its used is: 様子がおかしい！　Which means, Something funny is going on here! or Theres something funny about that person. You mean the homeless with a stuffed duck on his head? Yes. (FP)
    様 (important person) + 子 (child) = 様子 (the situation)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
様々 な ( さまざま な)
    All different kinds of xxx. Very similar to 色々（いろいろ）, but 様々 means more like "all the kinds of" rather than "many kinds of."
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
同様 に ( どうよう に)
    in the same way. For example, "In the same way caffeine perks up the mind, your dads naked pictures perk up the body."
    同 (same) + 様 (important person) = 同様 (in the same way)
    Star-16Star-16

To monotheists, there is only ONE BIG GOD in heaven. And he is a jealous god who uses his omnipotence to check up on you to make sure you arent doing anything with other deities. If he was a boyfriend, theyd call him a stalker. Im just saying.

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    to see a friend off - like as far as the train station.
    見 (look) + 送 (send) = 見送る (see off)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
送り仮名 ( おくりがな )
    these are the hiragana letters dangling from the end of kanji, like the "べる" in 食べる or the "り" in 送り仮名。 okurigana are useful because they cue you to pronounce the kanji using KUN yomi, rather than ON.
    送 (send) + 仮 (provisional) + 名 (name, famous) = 送り仮名 (okurigana)
    Star-16

    Take pretty much any noun you can think of, and aｄd "券" to the end, and you have invented a coupon for that noun.

    商品券： merchandise ＋ ken ＝ discount coupon . . .

xxx 長 (xxx ちょう )
    SUFFIX meaning "Boss of XXX." (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
社長 ( しゃちょう )
    company boss.
    社 (company) + 長 (long or boss) = 社長 (company boss.)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
長所 ( ちょうしょ )
    strong point, as opposed to weak point. Can be used about people (his 長所 is his courage, her 長所 is her brain) or machines (The strong point of this PC is its long battery-life)
    長 (long or boss) + 所 (area or attribute) = 長所 (good point)
    Star-16Star-16
身長 ( しんちょう )
    height (BOOBOO; only about human bodies- not about buildings or, well, anything else)
    身 ((ones own) flesh) + 長 (long or boss) = 身長 (height)
    Star-16Star-16
延長 する ( えんちょう する)
    extension or prolonging, in time. Also means,to extend a linear thing by building it longer. A bit more official than the related term 伸ばす　(のばす).
    延 (prolong) + 長 (long or boss) = 延長 (prolonging)
    Star-16Star-16

USED IN:

    張
    帳
    髪



Number: 921
張 stretch
Star-16Star-16Star-16
11 strokes
弓 (bow) + 長 (long or boss) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: CHOU

as in, "Its a stretch to call Margaret CHO funny. "

Stretch the bow until it is really long.

KUNYOMI:

は*る
    to physically make something longer. stretch a rubber-band、 stretch a canvas on a paint frame, pitch a tent. Also to extend ones influence.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

頑張る ( がんばる )
    No exact English equivalent. がんばる combines two English expressions: 1) do your best! 2) good luck! You tell your friends 頑張れ！ before a big test or job interview. (1 or 2 KANA, CCW)
    頑 (stubborn) + 張 (stretch) = 頑張る (good luck!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
緊張 する ( きんちょう する)
    stress, stretched to the max ーcan be used both literally and figuratively.
    緊 (tense) + 張 (stretch) = 緊張 (stress)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

全然 ( ぜんぜん )
    absolutely! (usually used to emphasize the word after it. But sometimes, the word being emphasized is omitted because its so obvious (to Japanese))

    If you hear someone say Zenzen! with no word after it, it might mean zenzen daijoubu, (Absolutely no problemo.) . . .

    OR it might mean zen zen dame! (No effing way, guy!) (1 or 2 KANA)
    全 (all) + 然 (nature) = 全然 (absolutely! )

Number: 954
除 exclude
Star-16Star-16Star-16
10 strokes
Town (town) + 余 (excess) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: JO

The people of Gaytown voted to exclude the excess women, so theyd have more places to Jack Off.

KUNYOMI:

のぞ*く
    The more hostile meaning is, to exclude, for instance: certain people.

    The more polite meaning is, to not count someone: "Not counting Bill, everyone here is republican." "Not counting Sarah, eveyrone here hates cats." "Except for one mistake, he did a good job!"
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    house-cleaning. Not just sweeping, but vacuuming, straightening up, smacking the futon, etc. (1 or 2 KANA, FP)
    掃 (sweep) + 除 (exclude) = 掃除 (house-cleaning)

    to remove or eliminate
    排 (eliminate) + 除 (exclude) = 排除 (to remove or eliminate )

If you GO too slowly, youll be excluded from TOWN.

(everyone is in a hurry there!)

Number: 958
界 the world
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
9 strokes
BETA
田 (rice field) + 介 (introduce or intervene) (Same-ON)

ONYOMI: KAI

Farmers used big KITEs, with their farms name printed on the underside, to introduce their rice to the world!
JUKUGO:

世界 ( せかい )
    the world, as in "biggest in the world!" "fastest in the world!"
    世 (society) + 界 (the world) = 世界 (the world)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
芸能界 ( げいのうかい )
    showbiz
    芸 (art) + 能 (talent) + 界 (the world) = 芸能界 (showbiz)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
境界 ( きょうかい )
    means border or boundary of property (80% the same usage as さかい　（境） , but a bit more formal).

    BOTH 境　and 境界　are often used in the figurative sense - like "This film pushes the envelope of good taste" or "His art blurs the boundary between painting and sculpture".

    Also used in science.
    境 (border) + 界 (the world) = 境界 (boundary)
    Star-16Star-16
xxx 界 (xxx かい )
    Suffix meaning, the world of XXX, as in 政界(せいかい) (the world of politics) or. . . . 芸能界 (げいのうかい) (the world of show biz)
    Star-16Star-16



Number: 959
合 to suit
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
6 strokes
ILL PAIR, DUPE, COCK
Peaked roof (peaked roof) + 口 (mouth or small box radical)

ONYOMI: GOU

You have a date tonight, so GO and find a Suit that suits you.

The peaked roof of the church suits Godzillas mouth. Mmmm delicious!!

DESCRIPTION: 合う gets the COCK because its the #1 offender for NOKURI AND the #1 offender for KUN ON. Put another way: not only does it use the KUNyomi in the jukugo, but it doesnt even use the KUNyomi properly! Its usually pronounced あい, but the い is not even written down.

KUNYOMI:

( に ) あ＊う
    to suit. The burlap sack suits your mamas hippo behind.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
( に　or と ) あ＊わせる
    to unify. To bring different things together and make them fit. Like a band tuning up is called 音合わせ (making the notes fit).
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

xxxの 場合 (xxxの ばあい )
    in the case of XXX (KUNKUN)
    場 (place) + 合 (to suit) = 場合 (in the case of XXX)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
に or が 似合う (に or が にあう )
    those clothes look good on you.
    似 (resemble) + 合 (to suit) = 似合う (suit)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
試合 ( しあい )
    a game (of pool, tennis, etc.) (KUN ON, NOKURI)
    試 (attempt to do) + 合 (to suit) = 試合 (game)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
都合 xxx ( つごう xxx)
    at your convenience, xxx. （ i.e. with the new hack, we can break into their system at will). (since the Endangered Raver act has been repealed, we can harpoon em whenever we feel like it). (FP)
    都 (major city) + 合 (to suit) = 都合 (at your convinience)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
組合 ( くみあい )
    a union or association (KUNKUN, NOKURI)
    組 (ones team) + 合 (to suit) = 組合 (a union or association)
    Star-16Star-16
集合 ( しゅうごう )
    a big meeting or assembly of people - can be used for business meeting as well as fun meeting like a concert.
    集 (collect) + 合 (to suit) = 集合 ( big meeting)
    Star-16Star-16
割合 ( わりあい )
    ratio (KUNKUN, NOKURI)
    割 (divide) + 合 (to suit) = 割合 (ratio)
    Star-16Star-16
都合がいい ( つごうがいい )
    located conveniently close to a place (FP)
    都 (major city) + 合 (to suit) = 都合がいい (convenient)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
会 	big meeting 	TWIN COWS 	云
合 	to suit 	MOUTH 	口

You have abig meeting with TWIN COWS. They say, "Dont eat us! We dont suit your MOUTH!"
USED IN:

    塔



Number: 960
給 provide
Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
BETA
糸 (string) + 合 (to suit)

ONYOMI: KYUU

If you provide me with the string, Ill make a CUTE suit that suits you.

DESCRIPTION: Sorry! The top 2 jukugo mean the same exact thing and are even 99% same-SOUNDING but you need both of them.
JUKUGO:

料 ( きゅうりょう )
    wages - a bit more useful than the related word 給与. For instance, payday is 給料日 (きゅうりょうび)、 not 給与日.
    給 (provide) + 料 (ingredients or fees) = 給料 (wages)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
供給 ( きょうきゅう )
    to supply (supply and demand or supply the troops with guns or supply your kid with a school lunches or the feed chute supplies grain to the conveyor belt at the cereal factory)
    供 (accompany) + 給 (provide) = 供給 (supply)
    Star-16Star-16
給与 ( きゅうよ )
    salary, wages
    給 (provide) + 与 (bestow) = 給与 (salary, wages )
    Star-16

    in fact. (as in, You think youre Samoan, but in fact, youre adopted.)

( が　or に or は ) かたよ＊る
    Figuratively, to be biased. Literally, to have an assymetrical distribution of objects. For example, "There are crows in every prefecture, but there is a much higher distribution of them in Aichi prefecture." Or,aesthetically speaking, "I put all the chairs on the left side of the room to make it かたよる."
    Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

偏見 のある　 or  ない ( へんけん のある　 or  ない)
    prejudice or bias　－not always racial
    偏 (be inclined) + 見 (look) = 偏見 (prejudice　)
    Star-16Star-16

Number: 995
論 make a case for
Star-16Star-16Star-16
15 strokes
BETA
言 (say) + Barbershop (bookstore)

ONYOMI: RON

RON Reagan talked in his speech, he made a case for keeping your Moms away from bookstores after she tried to mate with a Fabio cover.

DESCRIPTION: Unlike the related term 　議 (which also means to discuss)、論 is not reciprocal. I.e. you need two people to 議, but only one to 論.
JUKUGO:

論文 ( ろんぶん )
    an essay, like a senior thesis.
    論 (make a case for) + 文 (culture or  sentence) = 論文 (essay)
    Star-16Star-16
世論 ( よろん )
    public opinion
    世 (society) + 論 (make a case for) = 世論 (public opinion)
    Star-16Star-16
理論 ( りろん )
    theory, as in science or "theory vs. practice"
    理 (reason) + 論 (make a case for) = 理論 (theory)
    Star-16
討論 ( とうろん )
    discussion (NP)
    討 (attack or discuss) + 論 (make a case for) = 討論 (discussion)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
倫 	principles 	PERSON 	人
論 	make a case for 	TALK 	言

A PERSON has principles, but you TALK when you have discussion.

Number: 998
付 stick to

DESCRIPTION: COCK - its part of a lot of really useful jukugo

BUT

In jukugo, 付 is usually written in HIRAGANA, whereas the other kanji of the jukugo are still written in kanji. Why?

( を ) つ*ける

    be careful!

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    catch up to
    追 (follow) + 付 (stick to) = 追い付く (catch up to)

    find (your car keys that you thought youd lost)ー BOOBOO: you dont use 見つける about things youre discovering for the first time. Thats 発見 (はっけん）! (1 or 2 KANA)
    見 (look) + 付 (stick to) = 見付ける (find)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
気付いた ( きづいた )
    to belatedly realize something - doh! (also pronounced 気がついた）

    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    clean up the room or desk. Not just sweep the floor but like straighten up all the papers, put the pens in a row, etc.

    Star-16Star-16

    Star-16Star-16

    Star-16

    rusted or rusty (KANA)

    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
伐 	timmmberrr 	SPEAR 	Spearthree
代 	generation or instead of 	dot is on the outside 	
付 	stick to 	GLUE - dot is on the inside! 	寸

Timberrrr! is like Generation but with an EXTRA LINE -which you can think of as a SPEAR striking down a whole generation.

"Stick to" is the only kanji where the dot is on the inside, so you could think of it as a dot of GLUE making the left and right right radicals stick to each other.

Number: 1016
等 equal  or etc. or plural

KUNYOMI:

ひと*しい
    equivalent : usually in the mathematical sense, but can also be used figuratively, "Hes as good as dead!" "Your lies are tantamount to treason, and Ill see you hanged!!" This is closer to the non-judgemental 同じ than it is to the moralistic 公平　（fair)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

XXX 等 (XXX ら )
    SUFFIX . . . actually, its one of TWO Japanese suffixes that both mean plural. 等 is kind of a more macho suffix than 達(たち）, and its ONLY used in the following words : 彼等： かれら(them) . . . .and あいつ等：あいつら (those clowns) . . . and 奴等：やつら (those assholes over there) (SUF)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
等々 ( などなど )
    et cetera. (FP)
    Star-16Star-16
平等 に ( びょうどう に)
    impartial, even-steven. (to cut the cake into equal pieces, to treat your adopted kids and your biological kids equally) (FP)
    平 (equal or level) + 等 (equal  or etc. or plural) = 平等 (impartial, even)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical

等 	equal  or etc. or plural 	TEMPLE 	寺

My YOUNGER BROTHER comes after me in our family series.

According to the U.S. Constitution, all TEMPLES are equivalent.- Congress shall pass no law and etc.

Number: 1021
対 against
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
7 strokes
COCK
交 (combine) + 寸 (glueglue)

ONYOMI: TAI

I am against combining my neckTIE and a bottle of glue.

I think maybe a better way to keep it attached to my chest is to tie it in a knot around, say, my neck?

DESCRIPTION:COCK: By itself, it means pair as in a pair of tennis rackets. . . but in a jukugo it means "against" - the OPPOSITE of being a pair with.

Sheesh.

Luckily, the kunyomi is almost never used.

But still, that just makes it even more stupid.

KUNYOMI:

つい
    a pair 　
    - zero stars! -

Number: 1042
缶 can, like canned beef
Star-16Star-16Star-16
6 strokes
NEO, PRE
斤 (axe) + Pit (pit)

ONYOMI: KAN

In the old days before aluminum cans or KANs were invented, people would dig a pit with an axe and pour all their soup in there.

Then bears would drink most of it.

I mean, it was not a good time to be alive, people.

DESCRIPTION: the ONーyomi seems to be a neologism - When Westerners introduced tin cans, Japanese needed a word for em, so they re-purposed an obsolete kanji to mean "can" because it happened to be pronounced the same way!
JUKUGO:

缶 XXX ( かん XXX)
    PREFIX。 it means canned. 缶ビール is a can of beer. (PRE)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

    can opener
    Star-16

缶 	can, like canned beef 	AXE 	斤

    世 (society) + 中 (middle) = 世の中 (the world)

Number: 1045
葉 leaf

12 strokes
Flower (flowertop) + 世 (society) + 木 (tree)

ONYOMI:

Every year, the tree grows a new society of flowers and leaves.

KUNYOMI:

は*っぱ
    leaf
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

JUKUGO:

言葉 ( ことば )
    ANY word - unlike the related term 単語（たんご）、　言葉 can refer to compound words, or onomonopoeia. Also 言葉 can mean "way of speaking." There are expressions like "watch what you say!" that use 言葉 this way: 言葉使い が丁寧 (her way of speaking is very polite!) or 言葉大切につかいましょう （lets be careful how we speak!) (FP)
    言 (say) + 葉 (leaf) = 言葉 (any word)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
言葉遣い ( ことばづかい )
    ones choice of words (KANA)
    言 (say) + 葉 (leaf) + 遣 (apply) = 言葉遣い (ones choice of words)
    Star-16Star-16
葉書 ( はがき )
    postcard (KUNKUN)
    葉 (leaf) + 書 (write) = 葉書 (postcard)
    Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
喋 	speak 	MOUTH 	口
葉 	leaf 	FLOWER 	花

You talk to me with your MOUTH, about a leaf of a pretty FLOWER.

When you speak, your mouth says words (言葉).

失 	miss out on 	HEAD but NO PENIS 	
矢 	arrow 	NO HEAD 	

Vermillion has a dick between its legs (think of the bright red veins in a dick). Arrow and Miss dont have anything down there.

HOW TO TELL ARROW AND MISS APART: "失" has a little line sticking up at the top, which well call a HEAD. 矢has no head.

So you can say, "I MISS getting HEAD from your uncle ever since he got BEHEADED BY AN ARROW."

Number: 1056
擬 sham
Star-16
17 strokes
BETA, ILL PAIR
Hand (handleft) + 疑 (doubt)

ONYOMI: GI

You raise your hand up like, "Waaaait a minute, I doubt that you are real GEEse. Judging by your cardboard feathers and paste-on googly eyes, you are some motherfucking sham geese."

DESCRIPTION:This one is different from fake (偽) :it doesnt mean counterfeit or phony. It means sham as in a practice test, or a mock trial, or the model home in ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT where all the fruit in the kitchen was plastic. In other words, 擬 means a sham that is a mock-up or a model - its not meant to fool anyone.
JUKUGO:

擬態語 ( ぎたいご )
    擬態語 is a　very Japanese concept - a sound effect for something that doesnt make noise - usually emotional states. The only English example of 擬態語 I can think of is  bling. (1 or 2 KANA)
    擬 (sham) + 態 (looks like) + 語 (language) = 擬態語 (emotional sound-effect)
    Star-16
擬似 XXX ( ぎじ XXX)
    PREFIX meaning quasi-XXX (PRE)
    擬 (sham) + 似 (resemble) = 擬似 (quasi)
    Star-16
擬音語 ( ぎおんご )
    Onomatopoeia!!!! Sound-effect words. in English, that means words like slap smack or splash. (1 or 2 KANA)
    擬 (sham) + 音 (sound) + 語 (language) = 擬音語 (Onomatopoeia!)
    Star-16

    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16

    I dont know. (as opposed to "分からない" which means, i dont get it.)

お知らせ ( おしらせ )
    a flyer, or a sign on the wall - usually advertising an event.
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
承知 する ( しょうち する)
    to agree in theory　(business - speak). Stronger than 承る（うけたまわる）.

    承知 is what you say when you have heard and understood a business proposal, and you agree with it. It doesnt necessarily mean that you will sign the contract or do whatever the person says; merely that you want to work together with them to accomplish these goals, in theory, after 100 more meetings. (F, CCW)
    承 (to be told　 or  consent) + 知 (know) = 承知 (to agree in theory)
    Star-16Star-16

大失敗 ( だいしっぱい )
    a total disaster.
    大 (big) + 失­敗 (any failure! Flunking a test, your plan fails, no one comes to your party, your business goes bankrupt, your moms chest waxing goes wrong and her pec-fro winds up as Beyonces wig.) = 大失敗 (total disaster)
    Star-16Star-16

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
朱 	vermilion 	PENIS ON THE BOTTOM 	
失 	miss out on 	HEAD but NO PENIS 	
矢 	arrow 	NO HEAD 	

Vermillion has a dick between its legs (think of the bright red veins in a dick). Arrow and Miss dont have anything down there.

HOW TO TELL ARROW AND MISS APART: "失" has a little line sticking up at the top, which well call a HEAD. 矢has no head.

So you can say, "I MISS getting HEAD from your uncle ever since he got BEHEADED BY AN ARROW."
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
先 	earlier or  the tip 	LEGS OPEN 	
失 	miss out on 	LEGS CLOSED 	

1) Probably the first time you saw "先" , you were looking at the word for teacher (sensei)-- 先生

2) MISS is basically SENSEI but with its legs closer together. Therefore,

3) I missed out on sex with teacher because she kept her LEGS CLOSED.

See?
USED IN:

    鉄

    Star-16Star-16Star-16
( が ) つら＊なる

連絡 する ( れんらく する)
    to inform, to let someone know. Like, "Let me know if youre coming. Call me when you get there," kind of thing.

に 関連している (に かんれんしてる )

    関 (connected to) + 連 (take with or inform of) = 関連している (relevant)

	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical

運 	carry or luck 	SOLDIERS 	軍
連 	take with or inform of 	CAR 	車

Im HAPPY to have plural friends.

I need to carry SOLDIERS to the battle,

So Ill take them with me in my CAR.


Number: 1082
運 carry or luck
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
12 strokes
ILL PAIR, JERK
Moving (motion) + 軍 (army)

ONYOMI: UN

I wish the army luck when they move forward with their campaign - hopefully they only meet UN-armed civilians.

KUNYOMI:

はこ*ぶ
    to transport - unlike はいたつ(配達）, 運ぶ is NOT related to business or money. If you help your friend move his fridge to his new place, thats 運ぶ. If you pick up your suitcase and take it to the airport, thats 運ぶ。
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
うん
    luck (NUBI)
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

運転 する ( うんてん する)
    drive a vehicle
    運 (carry or luck) + 転 (roll over) = 運転 (drive a vehicle)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
運動 ( うんどう )
    exercise
    運 (carry or luck) + 動 (movement) = 運動 (する)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
運命 ( うんめい )
    fate
    運 (carry or luck) + 命 (life) = 運命 (fate)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
運がいい　 or  運が悪い ( うんがいい　 or 　うんがわるい )
    lucky or unlucky
    運 (carry or luck) + 悪 (bad) = 運がいい　 or  運が悪い (lucky or unlucky)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16

Number: 1087
剰 excessive
Star-16
11 strokes

ONYOMI: JOU

JUKUGO:

過剰 XXX ( かじょう XXX)
    PREFIX (sometimes SUFFIX!) meaning excessive - sometimes as in an overdose of drugs, an excess of personnel, but usually an excess of an attitude or behavior. This prefix is the only time youll ever see the 剰　kanji. (PRE)
    過 (surpass or too much) + 剰 (excessive) = 過剰 (excessive XXX)
    Star-16
自信過剰 ( じしんかじょう )

Number: 1090
働 to do your job

Homer says DOH as he schleps off to do his job.

DESCRIPTION:仕, 勤, and 働 all mean work, but 仕 emphasizes the job title, 働 emphasizes the physical labor on the job, and 勤 emphasizes to work AT such-and-such a company.

Number: 1092
非 injustice or mistake
Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
8 strokes
BETA, PK, DUH, SYMBOLIC

ONYOMI: HI

HEs crying because of the injustice

Usually the textbooks say to think of this as two streams of tears running down a face. Works for me.
JUKUGO:

是非 ( ぜひ )
    this has 2 meanings:

    1) in casual conversation, starting a sentence with zehi means, Absolutely! Ill get it done by hook or by crook! - also, youll hear ぜひおねがいします！ a lot, which means Thanks in advance for this favor. . . . .

    2) the propriety or morality of a certain course of action ( the kanji themselves translate to right + injustice). (1 or 2 KANA)
    是 (fer shure) + 非 (injustice or mistake) = 是非 (absolutely!)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
非常 ( ひじょう )
    emergency. This is the word on all the emergency exits and emergency firehoses. But youd never say "Im having an 非常！”
    非 (injustice or mistake) + 常 (usual) = 非常 (emergency)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16Star-16
非常 にxxx ( ひじょう にxxx)
    in an emergency? No! That would be too simple. ひじょうに means, exceedingly or extremely.
    非 (injustice or mistake) + 常 (usual) = 非常 (exceedingly xxx)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
非 XXXX ( XXXX)
    PREFIX meaning without xxx Usually words use the 不 or 無　 prefixes, but occasionally youll see a 非-word, like 非常識　（ひじょうしき）　(no common sense) 非対称的　（ひたいしょうてき）(asymmetrical).

    I guess if 不 is like un- and 無 is like without-, then 非- is like no-!! (PRE)
    Star-16

USED IN:

    輩
    悲
    罪
    俳
    排



Number: 1093
輩 older or younger colleague
Star-16Star-16Star-16
15 strokes
CCW, BETA
非 (injustice or mistake) + 車 (car)

ONYOMI: HAI

Is the guy writing this already an old fart? HAI.

It is injustice that my older classmates get to drive the car, but us sophomores dont!
JUKUGO:

先輩 ( せんぱい )
    Usually translated as "person ahead of you in school．"　(opp.後輩 (こうはい））. But the 先輩・後輩 system of unchanging, rigid heirarchy is in full effect all throughout Japanese society, from the punk scene to corporations and everywhere in between. People still call each other 先輩 40 years after they graduate. (CCW)
    先 (earlier or  the tip) + 輩 (older or younger colleague) = 先輩 (Person ahead of you at school)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
後輩 ( こうはい )
    someone younger than you in school
    後 (afterwards or behind) + 輩 (older or younger colleague) = 後輩 (someone younger than you in school)
    Star-16Star-16
年輩 の ( ねんぱい の)
    old person.
    年 (year) + 輩 (older or younger colleague) = 年輩 (old person.)
    Star-16

( を ) ぬ＊く
    I pluck or extract something - pluck a carrot out the ground, pluck out a gray hair, The mouse plucks the thorn out of the lions paw.If you bleach the color out of cloth or hair, youre 色を抜く. plucking the color out!

    something is plucked out

    coward - the nuance is someone who becomes paralyzed when the shit goes down. Someone who is too frightened to react.

    Star-16

    idiot( usually KANA, so one star : *) (KANA)

Number: 1107
希 uncommon
Star-16Star-16
7 strokes
メ (katakana me) + 布 (fabric)

ONYOMI: KI

You have an uncommon KEY, hold on to it until you find out what it opens.

It is uncommon to see this kind of fabric in May.

KUNYOMI:

まれ ( な )
    very similar to めずらしい(unusual), but more formal or newspapery. Also has the connotation of rare-because-its-valuable (endangered species, a rare talent, etc.) If you see a dog-turd shaped like Lyle Lovett, thats 珍しい , not まれ。
    Star-16Star-16
まれ ( に )
    once in a great while, seldom
    Star-16

JUKUGO:

希望 する ( きぼう する)
    A common-place, easily possible wish: "Id like an aisle seat." "Id like to fly nonstop."　希望 might be better translated as request: Customers wishing to request a child-seat for their infant please see the waiter.
    希 (uncommon) + 望 (desire) = 希望 (request)
    Star-16Star-16Star-16
希少 な ( きしょう な)
    useless, academic word for rare animals or plants. (NP)
    希 (uncommon) + 少 (a little (amount)) = 希少 (rare animals or plants)
    - zero stars! -

LOOKALIKES:
	Meaning 	Hint 	Radical
希 	uncommon 	"X" ON TOP 	
怖 	scary 	HEART 	心

X is a rare letter, but if it makes your HEART go doki doki, its scary.

    face in profile (KUNKUN)
    横 (side or arrogant) + 顔 (face) = 横顔 (face in profile)
    - zero stars! -

参 admit defeat or visit

( が or に ) まい＊る
    When you say まいた！！ it means, to say uncle, or　!No mas! (Confusingly, it can also mean Im fed up! Fuck this, Im outta here.)

    However, theres another meaning: to visit an important place.　（luckily, this JERK meaning is very formal and almost never used anymore)

    What is really fucked up is, usually when a word has 2 meanings, you can tell which meaning it is by the particle. But with MAIRU, both meanings use NI. (1 or 2 KANA, NP)
    Star-16Star-16

    Star-16

    a tragedy (BOOBOO: not as in a sad play, but as in someones sister died while giving birth. A dramatic tragedy is 悲劇　（ひげき） )
    惨 (wretched) + 事 (action or  incident) = 惨事 (tragedy)
    Star-16
悲惨 な ( ひさん な)
    terrible, harrowing, tragic. Usually used not about a single person’s misfortune but like the tragic cost of war, the terrible catastrophe that befell the small town in Godzilla’s path, etc.
    悲 (sad) + 惨 (wretched) = 悲惨 ( terrible)
